help-with-addisons-medical-journey.name: Addison
help-with-addisons-medical-journey.disease: ALCAPA (Anomalous Left Coronary Artery from the Pulmonary Artery)
help-with-addisons-medical-journey.title: Help with Addisons medical journey
help-with-addisons-medical-journey.description: I created this go fund me to take time off to care for my 8 week old while in the ICU and help with expenses(medical, food, travel, etc.) while away from work. Thank you for taking the time to read about her. Addisons storyThe biggest fear of our lives happened to our 8 week old baby on Saturday 4/17/21. Addison was having chest retractions and not breathing well. We took her to Mott children’s hospital and we were hoping for the best RSV or respiratory infection, after her first X-ray we knew something was wrong. It showed she had an enlarged heart, her heart was taking up most of the room in her chest cavity to where she couldn’t breathe well. After an echo of her heart we discovered she had a rare congenital heart defect called ALCAPA. 1 in 300000 have the same defect as her. Her coronary artery attached to her pulmonary artery instead of the aorta. This required emergency open heart surgery. She had her surgery on 4/19/21. This was a shock and unexpected health issue with our baby girl. This is still a long journey ahead for her. I know times have been difficult for many of us but we would greatly appreciate any donation. NO amount is too small. EVERY LITTTLE PENNY ADDS UP.

baby-annabelles-medical-fund.name: Annabelle
baby-annabelles-medical-fund.disease: Kagami Ogata Syndrome (Chromosome 14 deletion), pneumonia, pleural effusion, alpha Thalassemia
baby-annabelles-medical-fund.title: Baby Annabelle's Medical Fund
baby-annabelles-medical-fund.description: In light of recent events, I’ve decided to create a place for those who have been touched by sweet Annabelle, to read about her progress as well as a place where her parents can accept monetary donations in efforts to relieve some of their financial burdens. I want to first say on behalf of our entire extended family, how grateful we are for all who have kept Annabelle in their thoughts, well wishes, and offered to help in anyway. From a simple call, to meals, to places to stay that are closer to the hospital and medical advice, and so much more. It has not gone unnoticed. Annabelle is so loved. Annabelle is my niece and there is nothing I adore more than her sassy looks, sweet chubby cheeks and even her fascination with pulling my hair. She has so much personality and life within her, and has already been through so much more adversity than any child should be expected to endure.On May 23, 2017, we were overjoyed with the sweet gift of Annabelle, though did not join us without difficulties. After a few labor complications, she was quickly swept away by doctors before Mama Bekah and Dad, Jack, could hold her. For days, Annabelle was weak, swollen, and could not breathe or eat unsupervised and assisted. Despite countless doctors and nurses opinions, we still had no definitive answers. Eventually, Annabelle was transferred and admitted to  a more permanent home at Texas Childrens Hospital NICU in downtown Houston. Annabelle didn’t get to come home like every other little girl, her parents would have welcomed sleepless nights caused by late night feedings and diaper changes. Instead, they spent nights up wondering who could help their baby finally find relief, and help them find answers.Annabelle spent the following weeks on oxygen and eating through a feeding tube. She underwent numerous painful testing campaigns, studies, x-rays, and scans. Doctors, nurses, and specialists worked tirelessly, night and day to try to find out how to help Annabelle. We are forever grateful to those doctors and specialists, nurses, and all the staff at Texas Children’s. Thank you, every day for what you do for families like ours.Jack and Bekah were with Annabelle every day holding onto any glimmer of hope they could...Trying to be strong for their baby girl, and trying to be strong for each other. Even though it seemed as if life stopped, the expenses piled up...their jobs and paychecks took a back seat to their daughter. Jack lost his job and Bekah is compensated on an hourly basis. Medical bills, parking, gas bills, as well as regular bills like rent, insurance, and utilities, were all adding up..the bank account was struggling to stay afloat, even with both families help.Finally, there was a dim light at the end of the tunnel. We started to see some progress with our little fighter. Doctors told us they had discovered that Annabelle was missing part of her Chromosome 14. Features that often occur in people with this deletion include developmental delay, intellectual disability, behavioral problems and organ problems. Her deletion causes a disorder called Kagami Ogata Syndrome. There is no long-term data as this syndrome is so new and so rare. (  I beleive there have been less than 60 cases medically reported worldwide as of 2015). While Annabelle seemed to be on the better end of this diagnosis, we did not know if she would be able to walk, talk, stand, or eat orally without assistance. One thing we did know, is it would be a long road together.Once the G-tube surgery was complete and Annabelle grew a bit stronger, her parents were finally able to take her home to their apartment in Katy. Annabelle was finally home.Mom and Dad tried to get back on track. Jack continued to work on his graphic design jobs while Bekah went back to work but catching up proved to be more overwhelming than they could handle alone. While they worked hard to cut costs, like moving in with Jacks (my) parents and selling one of their cars, it just wasn’t enough to cover everything with the enormous medical bills flooding in. After all of these trials and tribulations, they lost their only vehicle in hurricane Harvey. It seemed like even Mother Nature was not on their side.Fast forward: On Thanksgiving, we celebrated Annabelle's 6 month birthday and reflected on how far she had come. We were so proud of her progress.Just a few short days later, Annabelle was rushed to the ER. Immediately upon evaluation, she was put on monitors due to her heavy labored breathing, and X-rays were taken. It all lead to the diagnosis of severe pneumonia. She was put on high flow oxygen, as her blood saturations were in the low 80s, and that did nothing, so we then moved up to a cpap machine, she held up fairly well on that from about 1 am in the morning till 5 am. She was admitted into the Texas children Pediatric ICU. Annabelle started panicking with the cpap on her face and started desaturation into the low 60s (her usual levels are at 100) and they made the decision to intubate her. Her second Xrays showed the pneumonia getting worse. Now with the intubation she is on a ventilator and is sedated. She’s so sick and weak..but she is the such a strong little girl. While her selfless parents have chosen to stay by their baby's side at the hospital, there are still bills piling up. Bekah even missed a job interview that would have provided better benefits. (we all know insurance helps soften the blow, but it does not leave you debt free) There will be so many unanswered questions for the rest of her life. We understand there are so many people in need, but if you feel you are led to donate or share Annabelle’s story, please do.  This will go to help Annabelle and her loving parents for the past, present and any future needs. I will be sure these funds go directly to bills associated with Annabelles medical needs.Update as of 4:45 pm 11/28/17 - from BekahToday they did an xray and found that her pneumonia inside her lungs had gotten better, however the pleural effusion (fluid outside the lungs) had gotten worse and the air between her lungs and chest worse as well. Almost 2 hours ago they inserted a chest tube to drain the fluid and air, and did a pic line in her femeral vein to help administer her medications. There is talk of a possible blood transfusion with her hemoglobin levels being so low, and we just had a echo which Thankfully showed that her heart is healthy. She has had some bradychardia (heart rate dropping) which they are attributing to the fentynol drip and the ventilator tube.  11/30 UPDATE from Bekah : today things have taken a bit of a turn for the worse. The infection in her lungs (which had previously gotten better), has come back in full force and worse. Additionally it has spread to her whole body now. Her hemoglobin count is worse again today, and we are still waiting on the hemotologist to come by and discuss our options, and the labs to come back that they sent this morning. (on top of all of this she has alpha Thalassemia) The pleural effusion is still draining through her chest tube, which is good. She started today with the opposite of a fever, 95 degrees which is not good either. So they did everything possible to get her temp back up to normal numbers. Also they have started ipv interventions which is basically them trying to break up the disease in her lungs to make it come out easier. Little bug is all swollen and puffy from all the fluids they're pumping into her12/1 Update: The fluid output from her chest tube changed to a cloudy/heavier substance. Samples have been sent up to the lab and they beleive it is chylous fluid ( basically lipd and at thats not breaking down in her stomach and it is going into her plearal effusion) so they cannot feed her milk anymore. Hemotologist just came and explained we need to do a blood transfusion asap. Her hemoglobin counts are at 6.3 and they usually start transfusion for anyone lower than 8. This can come with some complications but the Dr has assuerd as that this is a much safer process than it used to be.Doctors and pedi surgeons are keeping an eye on her abdomen as it is distended, but say for now her stomach feels soft enough to not take any further action.Her lungs are breathing over the machines now and the end goal is to get her off the ventilators so her lungs dont start to get lazy and forget what their job is.They are aso weaning her off of the sedation and pain medicine as babies bodies can start to become addicted very quickly. All will keep an eye on any withdrawel symtoms. 12/4 Update: Wide awake and wiggling for mommy and daddy today. It seems little miss has gotten a little too used to her sedation meds so they don't work for her as well anymore. Annabelles body is currently fighting off two pretty severe infections which they believe is the root of everything going on with her. Ecoli, Staph, and Strep. We are still hanging out on the ventilator, and her chest tube is still training copius amounts of viscous fluid, but her hemoglobin levels have been above her goal, since her blood transfusion, so YAY FOR THAT. Baby steps. We still have a long way to go here at TCH, they're thinking 3 weeks maybe more now . Today we are just thankful to spend the next 3 days here with her without having to leave.12/12 update: Annabelle is finally stable and extubated, and her chest tube is out. They have removed her 2 pivs and are using only her tunneled PIC line for her medications and her sedations. Little miss is not taking well to being weaned off her sedation from when she was intubated, not only is she still on low doses of her "before" medications, she is on HERIOC amounts of methadone, and Ativan to help ease her withdrawal. We are on Hi...gh flow oxygen still, and having a bit of a time weaning her off of that, and still on the heavy duty antibiotics for her 3 infections. She is now trying 5 MLS of milk to test her and see how her tummy handles it, while still getting iv lipids and tpn to make sure she gets her nutrition. Slow and steady recovery will win the race. Thank you for your continued prayers and concerns. All we want for Christmas is our baby home with us.12/15 Update: My heart is heavy. This is not the update I wanted to give.. Things have been looking up for the past week and we were finally feeling some relief and seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. Last night after work I stayed up with my sweet angel holding her and snuggling to about 4 am, she had gone down to 7 liters of oxygen and they were planning on weaning her down to a normal cannula and 4 liters. At 10 am they had to bump her up to 15 liters on her high fl...ow because she was coughing and retching (most likely from the withdrawal she is experiencing, and the fact they took her off IV methadone, Ativan, and clonodine, and switched her to PO versions of the drugs - meaning it was going into her g tube, and that means she was getting less of the drugs). Her nurse decided it would be good to give Annabelle tummy time (even though she was already retching and vomiting), and the vomiting got worse, I asked her to put her back on her back to calm things down, then pt, ot, and speech therapy came in 5 minutes later to asses her and play with her, as she was already feeling bad, things deteriorated VERY quickly with her being messed with, she started vomiting more and aspirating her vomit. Within 10 minutes they made the decision to intubate her again, she was desatting in the low 60s and it was necessary at that point. They ran rsv and flu tests and a full winter panel, all which have come back negative THANK GOD, did xray of her lungs and the pneumonia was better, there was some lung collapse however. Currently we are discussing different options with doctors on how to proceed with her lungs weak as they are and the aspirating problem. Thank you for your continued prayers and concerns. All we want is for her to be better. I just wanna hear her sweet voice and hold her in my arms again, things change so quickly in just 24 hours...Feel free to call, email or text me with any thoughts.

help-corey-pay-for-his-newborns-medical-.name: Archie Bennett
help-corey-pay-for-his-newborns-medical-.disease: cardiac arrest with resulting brain damage and respiratory failure
help-corey-pay-for-his-newborns-medical-.title: Help Corey pay for his newborns medical bills
help-corey-pay-for-his-newborns-medical-.description: Corey Bennett is an amazing employee and Father of 2 kids. He works long days to provide for his family. On October 25th, Archie, his third child was born. On Tuesday December 14th 2021, the unthinkable happened and Corey found himself doing what no Father should ever have to do in there life. While waiting on the ambulance to arrive Corey was performing CPR on his 7 week old son desperately trying to save his life. He was rushed to the hospital not breathing and no heartbeat. Once at the hospital they got a heart beat back however, baby Archie still could not breathe on his own. He was Taken by helicopter to Chattanooga Children’s Hostpital where he is currently on life support. The doctors are doing everything they can. At this point, the doctors are not very optimistic. Little Archie has little to no brain activity, and he can not breathe on his own at this time. All we have to cling to is hope….with such a tragic situation going on and all the medical expenses that will come along with it. Money is the LAST thing they need to worry about. Any and all donations will be greatly appreciated even just $1 Thank you all in advance and please pray for little Archie and the Bennett Family.

support-for-the-alfreds-journey-with-chi.name: Aspen
support-for-the-alfreds-journey-with-chi.title: Support for the Alfred's Journey with Child Cancer
support-for-the-alfreds-journey-with-chi.description:
Cancer 

Cannot cripple love

Cannot shatter hope

Cannot corrode Faith

Cannot kill friendships

Cannot suppress memories

Cannot invade the soul 

Cancer cannot stop a community from coming together!!



Bart and Lexi have laid their child, Aspen in the surgeon's arms, slept upright in hospital chairs, smiled through tears and found strength in prayers and family & community support during the most difficult time. 

We have been wondering how we can help- what can we do? 

There is a real superhero living in the heart of Aspen as she fights this battle with brain cancer! She is an inspiration. 

She will soon be starting her treatments in Edmonton and we can help ease the financial burdens that will come with the year ahead. 

The goal is to support the family as a whole through this time. There will be additional costs to travel, food, living expenses, making memories and we can help them with these costs so that they can focus on treatment and staying together through it all. 

If you are unable to donate at this time please share this post and say some prayers for Aspen and her family.

asa-walkers-medical-expenses.name: Asa Walker
asa-walkers-medical-expenses.title: Asa Walker's medical expenses
asa-walkers-medical-expenses.description: Hi. My name is Stephen Walker. Asa is my nephew, He was taken to the Golisano childrens hospital of southwest Florida for treatment . Asa is the youngest of 5 children of Jeffrey Walker and Megan Nash. The doctors have diagnosed him with  ALL - Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia.  On the 27th the doctors are installing the chemo port to start this 2.5 year journey.  The family's medical expenses are just starting and like everyone that knows this little boy and his family know how hard it is economically to survive when the parents can't work.  Thank you all in advance for your gifts of love to help his parents and siblings focus there love on Asa. I know how overwhelmed they are emotionally with this news but they are equally overwhelmed by the love and support from you all.  Thank you does not begin cover the gratitude .

baby-bratt-medical-expense-fund.name: Baby Bratt
baby-bratt-medical-expense-fund.title: Baby Bratt Medical Expense Fund
baby-bratt-medical-expense-fund.description: Anyone who knows Gordon and Kate, and their wonderful children....loves them! In the midst of this already challenging year, their 3 month old baby boy was rushed to the hospital with internal bleeding. He has been stabilized after a couple days of critical condition, but the doctors are unable to find a cause. He is undergoing testing to discover what he has.We are asking for prayers, and more concretely, any financial assistance to help ease what will surely be heavy hospital costs. Gordon and Kate are very self-reliant, but it is through the request of family and friends, that we are asking for support.

zte7xz-medical-expenses.name: Beau
zte7xz-medical-expenses.title: Baby Beau's Medical Expenses
zte7xz-medical-expenses.description:
Hi, Family & Friends, 



Baby Beau was born on 11/22/2022 four weeks early. He has had multiple hospital visits and is currently hospitalized at UMC Children’s Diamond Center.



I am hoping to raise funds to assist Joby and Brenna with the unexpected medical expenses. My son Joby is a Paramedic and Brenna is an ER Nurse both serving their community.



We are praying the specialists can diagnose him and he can go home in the near future. Brenna is still on Family Medical Leave and Joby has had to miss work multiple weeks

support-for-baby-bennys-medical-journey.name: Benny Cannon
support-for-baby-bennys-medical-journey.title: Support for Baby Benny's Medical Journey
support-for-baby-bennys-medical-journey.description:
If you know The Cannon Family, you know LOVE. You've felt their their genuine kindness in one way or another and now it's our turn to shower them with the love they have shown everyone and their communities for years. Their focus should be Benny, not the store, current bills and future medical bills. 



If you are unable to donate, a prayer and a share is just as appreciated. 



Here is the latest update on baby Benny as of 6/27/24 at 10pm: 



We are currently living everyone’s worst nightmare.

Benny was in an incident at daycare and was found unresponsive, at this time we do not know for how long. He was taken by helicopter to Children’s Mercy and He is currently in a medically induced coma to provide his body time to rest. We do not have much more information until he has time to rest and the doctors have time to get results back.

At this time Please pray SO hard for Benny, for a stable evening, no seizures, good results from his CT scan, and his little body to rest. 

Also pray for Travis and I as we navigate this obstacle, and for our girls as they are so confused! 

The next 24-72 hours are very very very critical for our baby boy. 

Please please please love on your babies tonight because you never know what tomorrow will bring.

Travis Cannon

baby-bensons-medical-battle-needs-you.name: Benson Juarez
baby-bensons-medical-battle-needs-you.disease: premature birth complications including brain bleeds, heart condition, respiratory disease, and eye disease
baby-bensons-medical-battle-needs-you.title: Baby Benson's Medical Battle Needs You
baby-bensons-medical-battle-needs-you.description:
Baby Benson is a fighter and we are asking for help for him and his family.



Benson arrived extremely premature on May 8, 2025, at just 25 weeks. His Mom had an emergency C-section, and Benson was delivered weighing just 1lb 7oz and was 12.5” long. He was immediately life flighted from the hospital in Eau Claire, WI, to the Children’s Hospital NICU in Marshfield WI.



Our dear friends, Benson’s parents, Brooklyn Frederick and Rob Juarez, both need to work full-time and are trying to spend as much time as possible at the NICU. The drive to the hospital from home is 1.5 hours. They are able to stay at the Ronald McDonald house as needed, but there are short-notice trips on work days due to Benson’s condition. Mom and Dad are stressed, scared, tired and trying to do all they can for their precious baby boy, while dealing with the financial issues caused by missed work and travel and medical expenses.



Unfortunately, Benson has suffered from multiple brain bleeds; he has a heart condition, respiratory disease and eye disease. He may need laser eye surgery before discharge. But Benson is a fighter and is improving! When he recently came off the ventilator, he was able to receive his first real bottle from Mom and Dad. The motto is “Benson Strong”!



When Benson comes home, hopefully by the end of August, there will continue to be doctor visits and follow-ups with specialists. Both Brooklyn and Rob will need to take unpaid time from work when he reaches that milestone. We are asking for help to ease the financial burden so Brooklyn and Rob can focus on Benson. The constant travel is expensive and the medical bills continue to add-up. In addition, Brooklyn and Rob are moving this week into a home that will be better for Benson’s recovery.



If you can spare any amount for a donation, it would go a long way to help Benson’s family. Prayers and well-wishes are also appreciated. All money raised here will go directly to Brooklyn and Rob, to help with travel, medical and other Benson-related expenses.



Thank you for your consideration! Please share this link with as many as possible! Updates on Benson’s health and new pictures will be provided on this page.

help-the-gosse-family-navigate-caring-fo.name: Bradlee Gosse
help-the-gosse-family-navigate-caring-fo.disease: Nephrotic Syndrome with Deep Vein Thrombosis and May Thurner Syndrome
help-the-gosse-family-navigate-caring-fo.title: Help the Gosse Family navigate caring for a sick kid.
help-the-gosse-family-navigate-caring-fo.description:
I am Hannah Fletcher, I am Auntie to the Gosse family. I want to introduce you to the members of the Gosse family: Brandon Gosse and his wife Tiffany, and their 4 kids Luke, Bradlee, Hunter and Sophie.

I started this go-fund-me to help raise money to cover medical, travel expenses and loss of wages. As they are navigating the ups and downs that come along with caring for a very sick child.





Back in February 2024 Bradlee fell numerous times in under 5 minutes. Knowing that that was out of the ordinary for her 13 year son Tiffany rushed Bradlee to the Grande Prairie Hospital. Through a few days of testing the Medical staff were able to determine the cause of Bradlees's falls. It is a condition called Nephrotic Syndrome.



What is Nephrotic Syndrome? It is a Auto immune disease with a Kidney disorder that causes your body to excrete to much protein into your urine it also causes low albumin blood levels and high blood lipids. The condition causes fatigue, swelling, mainly in your eyes, feet and ankles, and increases the risk of blood clots. Only 5% of people with Nephrotic Syndrome developed blood clots. While there is no cure for Nephrotic Syndrome a way to treat it is through albumin infusions and other expensive medications. It is a life long condition that Bradlee will have to navigate.





The first month Bradlee was in and out of the hospital. The G.P. medical team worked hard to get his levels stable and remain stable so that he could stay home and get back to the life of a 13 year old. His Vitals where good one day and the tanked the next. That's were the Medical Team from the Stollery Hospital in Edmonton came in. On March 15, 2024 Tiffany and Bradlee drove down to meet their new medical team and what was supposed to be a routine meet the team turned into a full weekend of tests and Albumin infusions. These infusions help stabilize his oedema levels and regulate his protein levels and are needed twice per week.







Tiffany and Bradlee where at the G.P. Hospital for a routine albumin infusion on the 2nd of April when they where informed that the Stollery hospital would be calling them to schedule Bradlee in for an ultrasound and a possible biopsy. The biopsy would be needed to determine which type of Nephrotic Syndrome Bradlee has and to determine which treatment would be most beneficial. On April 7 Tiffany received the call for them to travel to the Stollery to get the tests done. On their way down Bradlee's left leg had swollen up to two times the size of his right leg. Once they got to the hospital Tiffany asked to speak with the Doctor as she believed the swelling in Bradlee's leg was due to a blood clot. The Doctor agreed. Bradlee was taken for testing to find the clot. The tests revealed that Bradlee had a full DVT- Deep vain thrombosis along with a bi lateral palmary embolism that is asymptomatic. After locating the clot Bradlee had under gone a Thrombectomy procedure. Which is a fairly new procedure. Making Bradlee The 3rd child in Canada, the first child in Alberta and the first child in Canada with Nephrotic Syndrome to under go that type of surgery.



While conducting the surgery Bradlee's medical team found that he also has May Thurner Syndrome which only 23% of Canadians have. May Thurners syndrome is where an artery crosses over a vain putting pressure on the vain restricting the blood flow. This along side the Nephrotic syndrome made the perfect environment for blood clots to form. Bradlee will be on blood thinners for the rest of his life.



Tiffany is not able to work as she is Bradlee's primary caregiver. She is currently at the Stollery Hospital with Bradlee as his amazing medical team works to stabilize his condition. Brandon is keeping the home fires burning while working and taking care of the other 3 kids! (Luke, Hunter and Sophie)





Through all of this Bradlee and his family are still smiling. They are taking one day at a time!

On behalf of the Gosse family we thank you for any and all donations.

help-bryson-fight-child-cancer.name: Bryson Rosas
help-bryson-fight-child-cancer.title: Help Bryson Beat Child Cancer!
help-bryson-fight-child-cancer.description: (This campaign was started by Diana Bentley on behalf of Melissa & Aaron Rosas. All donations will go directly to Bryson & his family).PLEASE WE NEED YOUR HELP! for Bryson.Bryson is a sweet & active 5-year-old boy who enjoys sports, swimming and exploring outdoors.  He has a close bond to his baby sister,  Madelynn who is 3-yrs-old.  Unfortunately 2 years ago, Madelynn herself suffered a traumatic brain injury (caused by 3rd party care-provider).  She will continue to require specialized care in the years to come. Thru it all, Bryson has been her playful companion & fierce protector.  Seeing how he tenderly interacts with her is heart-warming. They’re best buds.Recently, Bryson fell ill. He was life-flighted from Bend, Oregon to Doernbecher hospital in Portland, where immediate brain surgery was performed. We were devastated to discover Bryson has numerous cancerous tumors,- and only one being operable.  After surgery, Bryson starts radiation and chemotherapy to battle the remaining tumors that have spread to his brain and spinal column.  Doctors have confirmed his diagnosis as Medulloblastoma, Grade 4.Bryson is a kind & well-mannered boy who always gives you a hug and kiss, says hello and goodbye, please and thank you, -your heart just breaks for him. For his parents to endure a second tragedy so soon after Madelynn’s, is unimaginable. Bryson’s parents are struggling to both care for Madelynn, who requires constant care, and pay for medical, travel & hotel expenses to stay with Bryson. His father, a well-respected police officer in Bend, has taken leave from his job and will run out of paid-leave well before Bryson’s treatment has been completed. His doctors are just beginning the fight to keep Bryson alive. Please help us during the battle against cancer for an amazing young boy, and lift up his parents spirits. Maddie misses playing with her older brother. And we need him to be healthy, active and exploring the world again.This well-respected family has endured much sorrow but have remained gracious, hopeful & focused. Any contributions that you can spare will be wholeheartedly received & sorely appreciated. Please keep Bryson in your prayers. Thank you for your support.

help-cassidy-fight-stage-4-neuroblastoma.name: Cassidy Crane
help-cassidy-fight-stage-4-neuroblastoma.title: Help Cassidy Fight Stage 4 Neuroblastoma
help-cassidy-fight-stage-4-neuroblastoma.description:
On Thursday, May 9th, my five-year-old niece Cassidy was diagnosed with a rare childhood cancer called neuroblastoma.



Cassidy is a bright, loving, child- she is full of energy and joy. Before this diagnosis, she showed no symptoms besides an intermittent tummy ache following what was thought to be a stomach virus a few weeks earlier. On May 8th, she woke up in discomfort, refused to eat or drink anything, and complained of chest pain, so my sister Tess took her to the ER. They were admitted to Boston Children's Hospital seven hours later, where she has since received her first round of chemotherapy.



Cassidy’s disease is high risk (equivalent to Stage 4), and she is currently undergoing treatment at Dana Farber/Boston Children’s Hospital. She will be receiving multiple rounds of chemotherapy in order to shrink the tumor before surgery, which will be followed by stem cell transplant, immunotherapy and radiation. Treatment is expected to last two years, much of it inpatient, barring complications.



We are so grateful for all the prayers and positive energy that friends and family have been sending to Cassidy, her mother Tess Wonson (my sister) and her father Fred Crane. They need all the love and support they can get. The financial burden of treatment and all of the associated costs will be significant. Any donations will help cover unanticipated expenses and ensure that Cassidy receives the best possible care and support as she fights against this disease.









Update 6/3/24: Thank you so much to everyone who has shared and donated- every little bit helps.  I'm going to continue sharing and will post updates here from time to time.

medical-fund-for-cassius-the-warrior-kid.name: Cassius
medical-fund-for-cassius-the-warrior-kid.title: Medical fund for Cassius the Warrior Kid
medical-fund-for-cassius-the-warrior-kid.description: We are raising funds for the Warrior Kid Cassius and his amazing Warrior Queen-Mama La-Toya. Cass will be undergoing medical treatments at SickKids for a minimum of 6 months (but may easily continue for 9 months or more). During this time, La-Toya is taking a leave from office work to be a full time caregiver and cheerleader to Cass in hospital. Being a full-time caregiver is emotionally and financially draining. On top of regular monthly bills (rent, utilities, etc.) La-Toya will have substantial additional expenses such as: medications and medical procedures not covered by OHIP or insurance, transportation to and from the hospital (all hours), prepared food for La-Toya to eat (both for in hospital and at home after a long day in the hospital), gifts for Cassius (to keep his spirits up and for holidays), and other unforeseen expenses. While we cannot help directly with La-Toya’s emotional labor, we can ease the financial burden, and thus give her piece of mind financially throughout this challenging process.

charlottes-childhood-cancer-journey.name: Charlotte Cruz
charlottes-childhood-cancer-journey.title: Charlotte's Childhood Cancer Journey
charlottes-childhood-cancer-journey.description:
Charlotte is an amazing 4-year-old girl who always has a smile on her face, a princess dress on her body, and a microphone in her hand. Her spirit and heart are contagious to all those around her. Recently, the Cruz Family received some news that turned their world upside down. Charlotte was diagnosed with Pre-B Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Doctors have put together a treatment plan of a minimum of 2.5 years, and Charlotte will begin with chemotherapy this week.



Jessica has dedicated her life to helping others through her line of work as a Nurse. Jessica and Nick are always the first ones to step up and lend a helping hand to others around them. Now, it's our turn to help them. The money raised will go towards medical expenses that will quickly add up, weekly trips to the hospital, and essentials for their beautiful family of 5. Every little bit of love counts and makes a huge difference in her fight to get the best care possible. Thank you all for helping in any way you can.

cjs-battle-with-cancer.name: CJ Nielsen
cjs-battle-with-cancer.title: CJ's Battle with Cancer
cjs-battle-with-cancer.description:
Meet CJ!



He is a spunky, intelligent, active and loveable three year old. He loves trains, planes, cars and his twin brother Cooper.





On May 3rd, CJ was admitted to the hospital due to a rapidly worsening jaundice. After a quick ultrasound, a mass was found on his liver. The surgeons originally thought it was benign and decided on a complete resection of the tumor. The surgery was successful and CJ started to recover well.





A week later, the pathology report came back and showed that the mass was not benign, but was in fact malignant. The tumor on his liver tested positive for Rhabdomyosarcoma, a muscle cancer. The treatment needed will be long and hard. CJ will undergo 42 weeks of chemo with radiation following the first 13 weeks.



CJ's mom and dad are Conner and Tamela Nielsen. Conner recently graduated from dental school at Loma Linda and will start Oral Maxillofacial Surgery residency at UCSF Fresno. Tamela has loved being a mom to her two boys the last 3 years, and frequently takes them to children's museums, hikes, and their favorite parks, they love being outside!





With financial and insurance needs, Conner will keep his residency position at UCSF Fresno, while Tamela, CJ, and Cooper will remain in Loma Linda (4 hours away from Fresno) so CJ can receive his care.



How can you help? With weekly chemotherapy and Conner being away, they need help with necessities like groceries, gas money for Conner to visit, and every day living needs to help ease the burden for Tamela and the boys as they begin this new way of life.

Join us in letting CJ's family know how much we love them. Every dollar helps.



Even if you are unable to donate at this time, please share this campaign with your friends and community, Through Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Tiktok, or email, it really does help tremendously!



I will continue to update this page as CJ progresses through his treatments.



Thank you!



-Erica

teamcoop-hospital-bills.name: Cooper
teamcoop-hospital-bills.disease: traumatic brain injury with skull fractures and brain bleeding
teamcoop-hospital-bills.title: #TEAMCOOP - Hospital Bills
teamcoop-hospital-bills.description: Hello Friends and Family,On Saturday October 19th, Elisha and Hunter got a devastating phone call that Cooper had been in a fight and was transported to Brigham City ER. He was hit in his head so hard that he was knocked out while standing , fell backwards to the ground, hitting his head on the asphalt, then  had a seizure. The other kid ran and fled the scene, while a couple of boys helped Cooper while he was seizing. Elisha and her family rushed to the Brigham City ER. Cooper was absolutely out of it and was not making sense at all and his poor little body was in shock.  Within the first few hours that he was there he had seized 5 times. Cooper was then life-flighted to Primary Children’s Hospital Trauma Unit, and was admitted to the ICU, and intubated for 48 hours. Cooper has several skull fractures as well as bleeding on his brain and bruising.  WHY IS THIS URGENT? Cooper was not insured at the time of the incident.  Elisha was in the process of adding Cooper to her medical plan, but with open enrollment, we all know that coverage will not be effective until January 1st 2020. Funds will help with hospital bills and Cooper’s ongoing rehab to ensure he is getting the proper care. In the event there are funds over the amount needed, Elisha is going to advocate and bring awareness to the severity of what can happen when kids fight and what a brain injury can do to our youth. Elisha will also give back to kids in need in our hospitals and any fundraisers for those in need.Cooper will have a long road to recovery. Cooper does not remember much about the event and his memory has suffered, he will need rehabilitation/ occupational therapy going forward. Cooper will not be able to return to school in a normal fashion and he will have to be home schooled for some time. A brain injury is very serious and if anything happens to Cooper over the next few months it could very well put him back into the hospital and the damages will be worse.Most of you know Elisha Ward.  She is one of the most positive and giving people that I know, and I can say that, because I have known here since I was a wee lass. Elisha is always taking care of everyone else, and is always one of the first people to reach out and offer help, volunteer her time and money for whatever cause or fundraiser there is.  Elisha is a single mother, raising 2 boys the best she can, and she always gives all she has to her boys, friends and strangers, and rarely takes the time for herself.  If you know Elisha like I do, she is also very prideful. She never asks for help on anything, she just buckles down and jumps in with both feet. And so when she said, Kate, I need help, I knew that her even asking for help was very hard for her.Friends, it is time for us to rally around this Momma and help her, the way she helps everyone else.The case is being investigated, so any information we have as far as what is going to happen next, is in the hands of the county attorneys.Elisha also has a Venmo account if you would rather donate that way - @Elisha-Ward-1

baby-cross-johnson-medical-expenses.name: Cross Johnson
baby-cross-johnson-medical-expenses.disease: kidney failure due to bladder outlet obstruction
baby-cross-johnson-medical-expenses.title: Baby Cross Johnson's Medical Expenses
baby-cross-johnson-medical-expenses.description: The Johnson family recently welcomed the newest member of their family -Cross Johnson - on June 17th 2021. Since baby Cross' arrival he has been fighting to remain healthy and become strong enough to go home. He has required extensive medical interventions for his lungs and will continue to need medical attention for his Kidneys, with the possibility of a kidney transplant down the road. We love Sarah and Matt dearly and ask that you bless them in anyway possible through prayer, or donation to help with medical expenses.Update from Sarah’s Facebook!Cross David Johnson was born June 17, 2021 at 37 weeks and 5 days, at 4:30 am weighing 7lbs 7oz. A middle of the night labor and birth was quite exciting, given that he was breech and we made it to the hospital in time for my first c section, and the neonatologist team to prepare for his arrival. Because of his extremely high risk pregnancy, our hospital was prepared for him to come. It’s been a rollercoaster since Cross has arrived. As soon as he was born he was taken straight to the NICU at Harris hospital. His first 48 hours in the NICU were really scary and sad. His lungs were really struggling. He was put on the ventilator, jet ventilator, nitric oxide and given surfactant. On the night of his second day, he made a huge leap and proved that he was a fighter! His lungs began to improve and he came off of a few machines, then he was stable enough to transfer over to Cooks Children’s Hospital. Once we got to Cooks, he had a few procedures done to get catheters and lines in place to begin dialysis because he was not producing any urine and both kidneys were showing to be non-functioning. On day 5 he came off the ventilator and began peritoneal dialysis. But over the course of the next 3 days this was not effective. His dialysis port was leaking really bad and he wasn’t draining properly. He took on 3 lbs of fluid and we needed to try something else. Cooks Children’s just started using a new machine called Aquadeks that preforms Aquapheresis. This is basically hemodialysis for babies and small kids. We are really fortunate our hospital just received this machine so we had the option to do the hemodialysis while his other dialysis port was healing. It’s only being used in 5 hospitals in the country. So on day 8, Cross had surgery to install the new port and began the Aquadeks machine. After 6 days on Aquadeks his swelling had all gone down and he was back to his birth weight and all of his labs were almost to normal ranges. So we went back to the peritoneal dialysis to give that a try again. Over the last 16 days of his life he has produced small amounts of urine but the nephrologists say in combination his kidneys are probably working at less than 10%. Our current goals are to get some consistency from the peritoneal dialysis and start removing some of the lines he has in. With the big picture being that he will eventually need a kidney transplant. Please pray for us and for Cross:-Pray that we find some routine amidst this journey while we juggle time at the nicu and time with the girls. -Pray that Cross’ kidneys would heal and grow and miraculously start to function. -Pray we can stay on the peritoneal dialysis as this is the only way for us to bring him home one day. -Pray for Norah and Shiloh as this is the most time we’ve ever spent away from them. We are so thankful for our friends and family who have loved us and supported us though all of this. I can’t even put into words what we have fully be through over the last 16 days but we are so thankful that Cross is alive and that he is fighting. Galatians 6:24 “May I never boast in anything but the CROSS of Jesus Christ.”Thank you Jesus for the most precious gift of Cross’ life!#bladderoutletobstruction

baby-daniels-fight-medical-help-needed.name: Daniel
baby-daniels-fight-medical-help-needed.disease: hydrocephalus, atrial septal defect, laryngomalacia, obstructive sleep apnea
baby-daniels-fight-medical-help-needed.title: Baby Daniel's Fight: Medical Help Needed
baby-daniels-fight-medical-help-needed.description:
Daniel was born prematurely at 34 weeks on November 21st. He spent 85 days in the NICU before being discharged to come home. He’s had many struggles, like learning to eat and breathing without oxygen support.
Daniel has an atrial septal defect in his heart, laryngomalacia (a floppy airway), difficulties eating by mouth, and obstructive sleep apnea. He received a supraglottoplasty back in January to open up his airway.
Recently, Daniel was diagnosed with hydrocephalus, which is a buildup of spinal fluid within the brain that can cause pressure, pain, and developmental delays. Daniel had another surgery, called an ETV (endoscopic third ventriculostomy) to help his brain drain the spinal fluid and relieve the pressure in his skull in late June. Unfortunately, the procedure failed to help him maintain the spinal fluid in his brain, and he required a shunt to be placed in early July. Daniel has a long road to recovery ahead of him, but he is resilient. This experience has been very heavy on myself and my husband, Keegan. Any donation is greatly appreciated to help cover medical bills and others medical expenses. Thank you!

support-illanas-twins-facing-major-surge.name: Daniel and Donald Mikhael
support-illanas-twins-facing-major-surge.title: Save Twins Lives Facing Major heart and GTube Surgeries
support-illanas-twins-facing-major-surge.description:
Hi everyone,



I’m asking for support for my sister Illana, a devoted mom to five young children. Her family has been through more than most could imagine, and the twins’ medical journey has reached another difficult chapter.



Both baby boys were born with Tetralogy of Fallot, a rare and serious congenital heart condition. They have spent much of their lives in and out of the hospital, undergoing procedures, living with feeding tubes, and fighting every day to grow and stay strong.



Illana is the person who primarily manages the boys’ medical care. She lovingly and tirelessly places their feeding tubes three to five times every single day, while juggling hospital stays, therapies, and endless doctor visits — all while caring for her other three little ones with so much love and grace.



Recently, things have become even more critical:

• Daniel underwent G-Tube surgery to safely receive the nutrition he needs.

• Donald Mikhael just had his third open-heart surgery, and he will be undergoing another important surgical procedure this December.



Both boys will also need multiple future cardiac catheterization procedures and additional open-heart surgeries as they grow.



This has meant more long days and nights in the hospital, more exhausting travel, and more expenses. Our parents help when they can, but the ongoing medical demands are still overwhelming.



If you can give anything — no matter how small — please know that 100% of all donations will go directly toward the twin boys’ medical and recovery needs: hospital bills, travel costs, therapies, medical supplies, groceries, and essentials for the children’s care and stability.



These donations are personal gifts made solely for the children’s medical expenses and family support during this long recovery journey. All funds will be managed transparently by Illana’s sister to ensure they are used only for the children’s well-being and household stability.



If you can’t give, please share this page and keep them in your prayers and your hearts. Every prayer, every share, and every kind word helps lighten their load.



Illana has always been the kind of mother who stays up all night at a hospital bedside and still wakes up with love and strength for her children in the morning. Now, she needs all of us to show up for her.



From the bottom of my heart, thank you for reading, caring, giving, and sharing. It truly means the world to our family right now.



With love and hope,

Her Sister

thumbs-up-for-declan-fighting-childhood-.name: Declan Lyons
thumbs-up-for-declan-fighting-childhood-.disease: Brain tumor (cerebellum) - cancer type pending diagnosis
thumbs-up-for-declan-fighting-childhood-.title: Thumbs Up For Dec: Fighting Childhood Cancer
thumbs-up-for-declan-fighting-childhood-.description:
Standing Strong with Declan: Join the #ThumbsUpforDec Movement



Meet sweet Declan Lyons, an energetic and loving 3-year-old boy, and twin brother to JB. Declan's days are filled with joy as he plays with trucks, cars, and his favorite sand and Play-Doh. He loves Disney movies, often quoting lines from classics like Cars and Toy Story. Outdoors, he's a bundle of energy, racing his toy fire truck through the neighborhood and reveling in the magic of playgrounds. You can often find him cheering on his big sister Mallory and older brother Kellen at hockey rinks and soccer fields.



Recently, the Lyons family's world turned upside down when weeks of headaches led to an MRI, revealing a tumor the size of a golf ball in Declan's cerebellum, the lower back of his brain. This brave young boy just underwent an arduous 9-hour surgery to remove the tumor, only to discover that it was indeed cancerous. Now, Declan and his loving family are faced with an unimaginable journey to battle childhood cancer.



As we await the specific diagnosis of the cancer Declan is bravely confronting, we are certain that the path ahead won't be easy. Currently, Declan's loved ones are holding their breath as he recovers from surgery, hoping to learn the extent of any mobility impacts he may face. They've been told to prepare for a year's worth of treatments, including chemotherapy, radiation, medications, frequent hospital visits, and inpatient stays.



The financial strain on the Lyons family is substantial. With medical bills piling up, the challenge of feeding a family of six, transportation costs, parking fees, and the need to maintain a sense of normalcy for their three other children who are active in sports and dance, the burden is simply overwhelming. Both Bobby and Sarah will potentially need to take unpaid leave from work to support Declan during his treatments.



Despite this formidable obstacle in their path, the Lyons family is determined to fight and navigate this brutal and unjust journey. They are not alone, as we stand beside them, ready to offer our unwavering support.



Your contributions will make a significant difference in Declan's battle against cancer. Every donation, no matter the size, will help alleviate the financial burden and allow the family to focus on what matters most – Declan's health, well-being, and full recovery.



Thank you for your love, support, and enduring compassion during this challenging time. Together, we can help Declan face this battle with strength and determination. Please share this campaign using #ThumbsUpForDec & #DeclanStrong to spread the word and garner even more support for a family we all love so deeply.



To follow Declan's journey, please visit https://caringbridge.org/visit/thumbsupfordec



With heartfelt gratitude,



Sarah's Friends (& UML Soccer Teammates),



(Kristin, Darcy, Kelly, Caitie, Beth, Ange, Marielle, & Carly)

medical-and-funeral-expenses-for-baby-do.name: Dominic Alexander Nava
medical-and-funeral-expenses-for-baby-do.title: Medical and funeral expenses for baby Dominic
medical-and-funeral-expenses-for-baby-do.description:
In honor of Dominic Alexander Nava, a son, brother, grandson, nephew, and cousin. At 37 weeks baby Dominic was diagnosed with a vein of “Galen Malformation” in his brain. Dominic was delivered on 09/26/2021 and rushed to Phoenix  children's Hospital. On 10/06/2021 Dominic went under a high-risk surgery to help heal part of his malformation to help his chances of survival. Baby Dominic was a fighter, and he will forever be missed and loved. Heaven has gained another angel.

 

We want to relief some stress away from Miranda and Marco in this difficult time in their life. We are looking to raise some money to help with medical bills and funeral expenses. If you can help our family, it would mean the world to all of us. Thank you in advance for your support.

 

Also, we want to humbly thank every single one of you that have been praying for our family and sending good positive vibes.

assist-our-family-during-babys-medical-c.name: Eli
assist-our-family-during-babys-medical-c.title: Help support us in the care of our medical needs baby
assist-our-family-during-babys-medical-c.description:
Our baby was born at 36 weeks and had a stay in the NICU for almost a month. He was sent home on oxygen and a feeding tube for a diagnoses of sleep apnea and troubles with swallowing. 

We are looking into continuous months of occupational therapy and work with the neuroscience specialists at the children's hospital. 

During this postpartum recovery period we are struggling to keep up with some of our bills, the biggest one we haven't been able to recieve much help with is our car payments.  

The amount we are requesting will cover the cost of our car payments as well as a little bit extra for unexpected prescription costs and fuel for appointments until I am cleared to go back to work after 12 weeks. 

I am greatful for job security as this time is very much needed for my body to heal as well as getting doctors and care personnel at up for Eli.

At this point anything helps, but being able to keep our vehicle is a huge need in medical care for our whole family.

help-support-ellie.name: Ellie
help-support-ellie.title: Help Support Ellie's fight against Leukemia
help-support-ellie.description:
Hi, my name is Kelsey and I'm here to ask for help for a fellow Cape Bretoner.

Leah and I have known each other since we were children, and although we haven't kept in touch as we got older, I want to make sure she has the help her and Ellie need at this very difficult time in their life.



Like me, Leah doesn't want to ask for help, but when a child is in need, I found out first hand that we help the child no matter what, letting the parent breathe a sigh of relief when that help show up without being asked. So let's help Leah breathe a little easier and help her focus all her energy into her baby girl.



Leah's sweet Ellie is only 18 months old and was diagnosed with Leukemia a few weeks ago. As a cancer warrior mom myself, I know how incredibly hard this journey can be. It is even harder when you have the worry of how bills are going to be paid. No parent should have to go through their child's cancer diagnosis wondering what they will do after treatment ends.



I hope that we can show Ellie and her mom Leah the same support we were shown in our time of need.

baby-enzos-heart-surgery-and-medical-exp.name: Enzo
baby-enzos-heart-surgery-and-medical-exp.title: Baby Enzo’s heart surgery and medical expenses
baby-enzos-heart-surgery-and-medical-exp.description:
Hi, my name is Madisen Glaze, and I am fundraising for my friends new baby, Enzo. Enzo was diagnosed with a congenital heart defect when his mom was 20 weeks pregnant. The heart defect he suffers from is called a Vascular Ring which means his aortic arch is not arched, it is wrapped around his esophagus and trachea compressing his airways and causing other problems. He was born in Boston due to being high risk and thankfully was born with minimal time in the NICU and followed by Boston Childrens. Over the last month, baby Enzo has become increasingly symptomatic from his heart condition and is set to go to Boston Childrens next week to be put under anesthesia for pre operative testing. His team made up of pediatric cardiologists, cardiothoracic surgeron, general surgeron, ORL doctor, ENT, gastroenterologist and pulmonologist out of Boston Childrens are creating a game plan for when Enzo will need heart surgery. It was originally planned for when he was 6 months old but due to his symptoms that timeline may be moved up. Some symptoms he suffers from is choking when eating, gasping for air, strider (noisy breathing,) he has difficulty laying on his back as it makes it harder to breathe and becomes pained from eating due to silent reflux from his condition. Enzo’s mom had to leave her full time job to take care of him as daycares would not accept the child with his symptoms. 






Enzo’s mom has been a social worker at Catholic Medical Center in NH and goes above and beyond for her patients with compassion and kindness. Anyone that knows Enzo’s mom, Taylor, knows what a big heart and kind person she is. As a single mom, Enzo’s medical expenses are quickly piling up and I am hoping to relieve some of that burden for them as they continue to embark on his medical journey. 






Thank you for your donations and well wishes for baby Enzo!

greer-and-estelle-need-help-with-medical.name: Estelle
greer-and-estelle-need-help-with-medical.title: Greer and Estelle need help with medical expenses
greer-and-estelle-need-help-with-medical.description: My niece Greer is a single mother to two beautiful girls. Her oldest daughter Estelle (Stelly) is the kind of kid that’s always smiling, always dancing. Estelle was diagnosed with dysplasia of her right hip. This has caused her right leg to grow slower than her left. Without surgery she was told she’d have an adulthood filled with pain and difficulty walking.  She had surgery today and her doctors are hopeful for a full recovery. However, she’s in a body cast for 12-18 weeks. We know her Medicare won’t cover all of the expenses. She will require full time care while casted and physical therapy later. I’m just trying to help ease some of the stress. Greer will have to be off work while Estelle recovers. Anything you can do to help will be a huge help and greatly appreciated.

evelyns-unexpected-medical-expenses.name: Evelyn
evelyns-unexpected-medical-expenses.disease: Type 4 choledochal cyst with blocked bile duct
evelyns-unexpected-medical-expenses.title: Evelyn’s medical expenses
evelyns-unexpected-medical-expenses.description:
Hello Friends & Family.

Gallegos family here raising funds for our sweet Evey.



Our little Evelyn has been having health issues for the past 3 months. It started with what we thought were allergies, since she had been complaining about being itchy. It got to the point where I knew something was off, so we took her to the pediatrician and they had to get bloodwork. From there, it turned into many specialist appointments, to then getting an emergency admission to the Children’s hospital at the end of September. Everything from then until now has been so overwhelming and just a complete shock.



Our baby girl had been dealing with something far worse than what we could’ve ever imagined. We found out that she had developed jaundice, caused by a blocked duct that goes from the liver/ gallbladder/ down to her intestine. Initially, we were told that they weren’t sure what was blocking the duct, but they knew something was there because it showed up in a sonogram she got. There was speculation of all sorts of scary diagnosis, but we wouldn’t know for sure until that first hospital admission.



The first stay was to run more tests and to get some procedures done. We found out that she actually had a type 4 cohlydocal cyst blocking most of her duct and some sludge/ stones that had been building up. It was causing her to itch so much, and to have other uncomfortable symptoms. She got an MRCP & an ERCP done to clear that sludge, and put in a stent to help keep it clear and also help with inflammation that was causing her body to react.



We got discharged while the doctors finalized their plans, but we knew she’d have to get things removed because of cancer risks. We tried our best making those last normal weeks with her memorable.



Tuesday was surgery day, one of the hardest days of our lives. I can’t tell you how many times i’ve cried, prayed, wished it wasn’t real, but this has become our new reality. Her gallbladder and cyst were taken out, as well as the stent, and to repair the remaining duct to the intestine. A 3 hour surgery turned into 5 hours, but they managed to repair everything and she is currently recovering for the rest of the week.



Its been hard for her understandably, us as well. This surgery is life changing, but vital to her health. She has been soo strong and brave through it all. She amazes me everyday, a true warrior. If you know about Evelyn, you know just how sacred she already is to us since we almost lost her in the womb. Both my kids are my world, and it hurts us so much to see her going through something like this. Our hope after this is that her body is able to completely recover and not have any further complications because there are risks we still have to look out for. Her liver ducts had gotten inflamed as well, but we’re praying that after this surgery they can go back to normal. If not, there were talks about a liver transplant. I refuse to accept that for her because we have hope.



Please keep us all in your prayers, especially our little rainbow baby. That her little body is able to completely heal itself, and that she has no further complications and is able to live a full healthy life after this.



I created a gofundme to help with current and near future medical bills for her. It would also help tremendously with her 6+ month aftercare, etc. Thank you❤️

fighting-childhood-cancer-the-evie-fund.name: Evelyn
fighting-childhood-cancer-the-evie-fund.disease: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with KMT2A chromosomal genetic mutation
fighting-childhood-cancer-the-evie-fund.title: Fighting Childhood Cancer - The Evie Fund
fighting-childhood-cancer-the-evie-fund.description:
In honor of the 2nd anniversary of Evie’s bone marrow transplant on March 10th, our family is donating $25,000 via The Evie Fund at Children's Wisconsin to support Dr. Julie-An Talano's transplant research.



We are seeking to raise an additional $25,000+ from friends, family, and anyone who wants to fight back against childhood cancer. All donations are tax deductible, and will go directly towards continuing the research that saved Evie's life.



Evie's Story



At 7:45pm on November 18th, 2021, we were told that our 6 week old daughter Evelyn had Leukemia.





Soon after Evie was born, she started to develop bruises all over her body. At her one month well-baby visit, her doctor recommended we see a dermatologist just to be safe.



As we learned, the bruises were actually what is called leukemia cutis - blood cancer that was causing lesions under her skin. That night, we sat there holding her tiny body, staring at the disease that was trying to kill her. How could this happen?



Time stopped for our family after the diagnosis. Somehow, we continued on, our bodies living and moving through each of those initial days as though in a trance, thinking about how odd it was to have to do “normal” things like changing diapers when our baby was unlikely to make it to her first birthday. The feeling was utter hopelessness.



But Evie did make it to her first birthday. And her second. And she didn’t just make it - she lives life with a sweetness and intensity that brings smiles and joy to everyone around her.





Evie made it thanks to the efforts of Dr. Julie-An Talano and the unbelievable team of doctors, nurses, researchers, and supporting staff at Children’s Wisconsin.



Recent advancements in the evaluation and treatment of infant leukemia, including numerous contributions by Dr. Talano, are why Evie is alive today. Initial genetic testing quickly confirmed that Evie had a sub-type of leukemia called acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that was caused by a chromosomal genetic mutation, KMT2A.



Research showed that less than half of children with this genetic mutation survived on standard chemotherapy protocols. Thanks to advances made in the last 8-10 years, we knew that Evie was headed for bone marrow transplant, where her chances of two-year survival jumped to over 70%.



While the survival rate increases with a bone marrow transplant, they also rely on finding suitable donors - typically a sibling or one of the 40 million donors in the NMDP global donor registry.



In one of the lowest moments of our lives, we learned that Evie did not have a suitable genetic match for transplant from either of these routes. Once again, thanks to protocols and techniques established within the last decade, and championed by Dr. Talano, we were able to proceed with a stem cell transplant using Kim (mom) as Evie's donor.



Evie's transplant was a success. In total, we endured 5 months of inpatient treatment, 6 months of intense outpatient treatment, and a host of bumps and scares along the way. The last two years have been both a dream and a nightmare. We are not out of the woods, but we are extremely fortunate, and we've learned to cherish every moment we've been given.





10 years ago, Evie would've had almost no chance of survival without a donor match. Now, her odds are high and climbing every day she remains cancer free.



What can we accomplish if we help fund the next 10 years of research?





Thank you all, and Go Evie Go!



-Paul and Kim

help-the-huneycutt-family-fight-children.name: Evelyn Huneycutt
help-the-huneycutt-family-fight-children.title: Help the Huneycutt Family Fight Children’s Cancer
help-the-huneycutt-family-fight-children.description:
The Huneycutt family, who are an important part of the Orlando and Jewish community, are in need of our help. Evelyn, their youngest daughter, is a spunky little 4 year old beautiful girl who was admitted Monday night to the Orlando hospital where she was diagnosed with Children’s Leukemia (ALL). We are all hopeful and confident they will make it through this struggle with the strong family, friends, and medical staff around them, including her three strong big brothers.



They still need our help though and I’m asking for the community that they’ve been a part of for so long to come together for Evelyn.







Despite her blood counts being extremely low and requiring transfusion, a hard time getting a central line to start chemo and lots of other scary new things for the family along the way, Evelyn has been very brave and stayed the same happy sweet girl we have all grown to love.





The family is currently at the Advent Health Orlando for children who have been amazing. It will be their home away from home on their journey these next few years including the next 6 months of intensive chemo followed by 2 years of continued treatment and testing. They are not sure what the next few years may truly be like and are fighting to make the most of every single day!



We are fighting to help give Evelyn and her family the support they need to get through it. These funds will go towards helping them keep Evelyn happy, comfortable, and entertained during her stressful time. It will also go towards helping the family with meals, bills, and unknown expenses along the way so they can focus on being there for their daughter and sister’s journey back to health.









This process is a costly one that is tolling on the entire family, even one as loved and supported as theirs. While they are all pushing through a smile to keep Evelyn’s spirits high, I know that Britney and Kyle are fighting on the inside to be strong parents for their child, family, and community. I put this page together to ask a caring community to help make a difference for a beautiful, inspirational, and loving little girl who may not know it but needs our help now more than ever.





Please consider making a small donation to help cover the extensive unexpected costs and to provide Evelyn and their family the support they need to get through these tough times. Thank you everyone for taking the time to read this, for your thoughts, and your prayers! ❤️















Any remaining funds will go towards helping fight children’s leukemia!

baby-gabriels-struggle-medical-costs.name: Gabriel
baby-gabriels-struggle-medical-costs.disease: intestinal blockage with colostomy complications, fibrosis, and kidney dysfunction
baby-gabriels-struggle-medical-costs.title: Baby Gabriel's Struggle: Medical Costs
baby-gabriels-struggle-medical-costs.description:
Help baby Gabriel recover from medical negligence and malpractice







Baby Gabriel was born on August 24, 2023. He seemed to have been born a healthy baby until his first two days of life. He was rushed to medical care due to a blockage in his intestine and required colostomy surgery.







After frequent visits to the emergency room and treatment at Driscoll Children’s Hospital in Edinburg, TX, Gabriel’s mother knew he was in urgent need of another doctor’s opinion and evaluation. A doctor in Colorado, an angel in disguise, looked over Gabriel’s medical history and confirmed medical negligence. Gabriel’s mother had no choice but to get private insurance to have surgery done in Colorado. He suggested an emergency surgery to do a colostomy reversal, but it had been too late. Gabriel’s intestine had developed fibrosis, and the surgery wasn’t successful. There have been 5 surgeries with baby Gabriel, and no one had discovered his kidney is only working 30%. He now has to undergo yet another surgery. More than $50K has gone to baby Gabriel’s medical expenses, which has left his family with a financial burden. The family will use these funds to cover medical expenses.







Thank you for your donations and God bless you.

hope-for-harper-help-fight-rare-pediatri.name: Harper
hope-for-harper-help-fight-rare-pediatri.title: Support Harper & Help Fight Rare Pediatric Cancer
hope-for-harper-help-fight-rare-pediatri.description:
Join Harper's Fight Against Cancer and Stand Up for Kids with Rare Cancers.







Harper is a 1.5-year-old warrior who has been battling stage 3 ovarian cancer since she was 10 months old. While perfectly healthy up until that day in November, her dad noticed a hard mass in her abdomen while changing her diaper. We took Harper to pediatric urgent care as well as her pediatrician, and the doctors believed this mass was due to constipation. As her parents, we pushed for an ultrasound, believing in our gut that something was not right, and as a result, on 12/3/2024, doctors discovered an 11 cm Sertoli-cell ovarian tumor that had already spread to her lymph nodes. Nothing can prepare a parent to hear the news that their child has cancer. Harper's cancer is incredibly rare and, according to her doctors, the youngest recorded case of this tumor that they can find. With very little information out there, her doctors have been working tirelessly to come up with the best plan for treatment, not knowing whether chemotherapy will work and if so, which drugs will be effective.







Harper is being treated at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and has demonstrated strength, resilience, and bravery through every step of this battle. The day after discovering the tumor, she had surgery to remove her ovary, fallopian tube, and some pelvic lymph nodes. Since then, she has received 7 rounds of chemotherapy as well as the awful side effects that come with it. Harper had two more 8-hour surgeries (in March and June) to dissect retroperitoneal lymph nodes that were infected as well. With such little information available regarding Sertoli-cell tumors in babies, Harper continues to be monitored frequently with MRI scans as well as PET scans. We are hopeful that the worst is behind us but are also very aware that any changes on these scans will lead to further surgeries and treatment.







Hope for Harper







Harper demonstrates her resilience and strength every single day. She has the chubbiest cheeks and the best smile. From the time she was 10 months old, she endured 3 major abdominal surgeries, impacting her core strength and ability to learn to walk. With the help of rehabilitation doctors, physical therapists, and custom orthotics, at 19 months old, Harper began to walk. Within weeks of learning to take her first steps, she was already trying to ride her big sisters' scooters around. Harper is a force to be reckoned with, and despite so many nights spent in the hospital, the chemotherapy, needles, anesthesia, surgeries, scars, hair loss, neuropathy, medicine, and vomiting, she wakes up happy and with the biggest smile on her face. While only 20 months old, Harper speaks in sentences and loves to boss her parents and sisters around.







Your Support Helps







We have been overwhelmed by the outpouring of love and support from family, friends, and strangers. So many people have reached out over the last 10 months through messages, care packages, meals, or simply asking how they can help. We never imagined ourselves to be in this position, but the love and support we have received has helped us through some of the most difficult days. Harper's mom has taken leave from work for the time being to help support her through ongoing doctor appointments, scans, and physical therapy.







While we do not yet know what Harper's medical expenses will look like long-term, we have been managing for now. We hesitated to set up a GoFundMe for that very reason. However, through many generous and caring people reaching out, we recognize that many people want to contribute in a meaningful way. Funds raised will go directly toward Harper's medical care and related expenses as well as funding research for rare pediatric cancers through MSK.







How You Can Help







Your support, whether through a donation, sharing this page, or simply keeping Harper in your prayers, means the world to us. Every contribution, big or small, will help support Harper's fight while also advancing research to give hope to other children battling rare cancers.







We have an amazing team of doctors at MSKCC. Harper's oncologist, Dr. Julia Glade-Bender, surgeon Dr. Justin Gerstle and Talia Sauerhaft, NP, are just a few of the incredible heroes fighting tirelessly for our little girl and other children battling rare cancers. They have provided exceptional care and unwavering dedication. We are beyond grateful for their expertise, compassion, and commitment to advancing treatments for children like Harper.







From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for standing with us, for Harper, and for every child fighting this fight.

support-3-year-old-harper-family.name: Harper Raye Fraps
support-3-year-old-harper-family.title: Support 3 Year Old Harper & Family
support-3-year-old-harper-family.description:
My name is Jessie Joye, stepsister to Jeffrey Fraps. Jeffrey, Marcus, and I shared the loss of a brother, Michael, when he was two. A lifetime of heartache, anger, and often time isolation followed our family. No one should have to go through this twice. And yet, here we are…again.  



My brother Jeffrey and his wife, Kara, have embarked on their own nightmare of despair and uncertainty with one of their own little princesses, Harper Raye.  Jeffrey and Kara need your help right now more than ever. Their beautiful blue eyed three year old little Harper is under sedation as they await the unknown.  Acid from a swallowed battery slowly eats away through her esophagus traveling directly towards an artery to her heart. With multiple recommendations to save her and all of them life threatening.  Jeffrey’s life as he knows it is at a stand still. 



A mother’s instinct is the one thing that Harper has in her favor. A junk drawer is where most household batteries are placed. When Kara noticed a battery cover had fallen off a toy she immediately removed the battery and placed it in the junk drawer. Some time later she noticed the drawer was open and observed that the battery was missing. Because of their swift actions and rushing Harper to emergency they have given her the gift we are most blessed to be given, time.



Kara, Harper, and Harper’s 7 week old sister, Elaina will be flying to Stanford immediately. Jeffrey, Raylee age 9 and Kenzie age 7 will follow shortly behind them by car. They will be in California for up to two months where they have a two month window of possible risk to Harper’s heart. She will be under 24 hour observation with her family next to her. 



Jeff and Kara’s income is based solely on their own business where Jeff plows away snow and manages residential property maintenance, himself. Family and friends have come forward to carry on business needs for Jeff while he is gone but this is not sustaining. Until they know how they will recover financially any immediate help they can receive now will remove a burden that should never interfere with the hope and healing of a child. Medical Expenses are guaranteed to be high, including travel costs, and business losses. The future financial burden is inevitable but the gift you can provide today will make one small obstacle during this storm, bearable. 



When asked for something to share from Harper’s parents all they wanted to do was share about their little Harper:



“She is the sweetest most loving big and little sister in the whole world! She is a best friend to everyone especially her mommy and daddy ❤ Harper loves to color and play with her cocomelon toys! She loves to be with her big sisters and is enjoying every minute with baby Elaina. She is so much fun to talk to and her imagination is endless. Harper is the sweetest little girl and wants to make best friends and ‘Go to school to make more little friends.’ Her favorite movie is toy story.”



Let your prayers, love and support go ‘to infinity and beyond!”

help-little-hazal-fight-leukemia.name: Hazel
help-little-hazal-fight-leukemia.title: Help Little Hazel Fight Leukemia
help-little-hazal-fight-leukemia.description:
Dear friends, family, and kind-hearted supporters,



We are reaching out with heavy hearts to ask for your support for this family from Chatham Ontario who have a beautiful 7-year-old girl named Hazel, who has been diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of leukemia.



Hazel’s world changed overnight. Once a bubbly, energetic little girl full of laughter and life, she is now courageously battling cancer with a strength far beyond her years. Her parents, Chris and Stephanie, have been by her side every step of the way—traveling back and forth from their home to the Ronald McDonald Children’s Cancer Centre in London, Ontario, where Hazel is receiving intensive treatment. While still caring and focusing on there other 14 year old daughter Lillie.



As you can imagine, this journey has taken an emotional, physical, and financial toll on the family. Chris and Stephanie have had to take extended time off work to care for Hazel full-time, attend countless medical appointments, and manage the difficult day-to-day realities of having a child with cancer. The mounting travel costs, hospital stays, meals, and lost income are creating a serious financial burden—on top of the unimaginable emotional stress they are already enduring.



We are creating this GoFundMe to help ease the pressure on this loving family so they can focus entirely on what matters most: helping Hazel heal.



Your donation—no matter the amount—will go directly toward:



Travel and accommodation expenses for treatments in London



Day-to-day living costs while Chris and Stephanie are off work



Medical-related expenses not covered by insurance



Support for Hazel's ongoing care and comfort



Hazel is a fighter, and her family is doing everything they can to support her through this battle. But they need our help. Please consider donating or sharing this campaign to help bring hope, stability, and a little peace to a family in crisis.



Thank you from the bottom of our hearts for your generosity, kindness, and prayers.



With love,



#HazalStrong #HelpHazalHeal

hudsons-childhood-cancer-journey.name: Hudson Adamo
hudsons-childhood-cancer-journey.title: Hudson's Childhood Cancer Journey
hudsons-childhood-cancer-journey.description:
Hudson is an amazing 6 year old boy who always has a smile on his face. His spirit and heart is contagious to all those around him.
