Recently, the Adamo Family received some news that turned their world upside down. Hudson was diagnosed with advanced stages of cancer. Doctors have put together a treatment plan of 3-5 years and Hudson will begin with chemotherapy this week.



Calla and Mike have dedicated their life to helping others though their lines of work as an ER Nurse and Firefighter. They are always the first ones to step up and lend a helping hand to others around them. Now, its our turn to help them. The money raised will go towards medical expenses that will quickly add up, weekly trips to Children's Hospital, and essentials for their beautiful family of 6.

izzys-medical.name: Izzy
izzys-medical.disease: Systemic Scleroderma and bladder birth defect with ureter reflux and hutch diverticulum
izzys-medical.title: Izzy's Medical Needs
izzys-medical.description:
Izzy (6 yrs old on August 5th) was diagnosed with Systemic Scleroderma when she was a year and a half old, so she's no stranger to doctors and hospitals. This time we're not dealing her Scleroderma, we're dealing with a birth defect in her bladder.

---

Scleroderma is a rare disease that affects connective tissue and the vascular system. Generally classified as an autoimmune rheumatic disease, an overproduction of collagen (fibrosis) hardens tissue and damages organs. Commonly affecting the skin (called localized), scleroderma also affects internal organs (systemic sclerosis) and can be life-threatening. Anyone can have scleroderma. No one knows what causes the disease, although there are many clues including genetic predisposition. There is no cure and no drugs that halt the progression of the disease or reverse it. The fibrosis at the center of scleroderma makes it prototypic for all other fibrotic diseases.

---

She has reflux in her ureter tubes and at least one hutch diverticulum in her bladder caused by a thin bladder wall. A third doctor claims he sees a second hutch. But we aren't sure. (A hutch is a pocket on the side of her bladder that holds urine and becomes easily infected.) Her ureter tubes have reflux meaning her urine is going back up into her kidney causing infection. This means that Izzy can't control her bladder and is constantly getting kidney and bladder infections. She starts school in a few weeks and will have to deal with incontinence in the middle of a class full of kids. Surgery is scheduled for Sept 9th. Until they go in and see what's going on they aren't sure if they're going to repair the hutch and the tubes, or if they're just going to do what's called a deflux to prevent the reflux of urine in the tubes. So she may be in the hospital 24hrs or an entire week depending on what they find.

Payment is due the week before the surgery for Izzy's urologist, Dr. Nosnik's portion. Dr. Nosnik has been her urologist for over a year so he knows the case well. His price for the surgery is $8,253.00.

We are still waiting on Dallas Children's to call us with a price that they'll send to her Medi-Share insurance plan. We won't know how much medi-share will pay, if any, until after we file the bill after the procedure. She was recently in the hospital for a week at Cook's Children's Hospital Fort Worth and the cost for that stay was around 23k, with no help from insurance.

We're trying to help Izzy's mom, Tessa, with bills so she doesn't have to worry about how to pay while focusing on Izzy getting better. Anything you can donate will help.

jacer-all.name: Jace Russell
jacer-all.title: Baby Jace's Medical Expenses
jacer-all.description: As some may know, what was suppose to be a normal pediatrician visit turned into something much more for the Russell family. On December 13, 2017, Jace was diagnosed with B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Jace will be visiting Texas Childrens Hospital in Houston once a week for 9 months for treatment and if all goes well once a month for 2 and a half years. His parents, Jill and Justin are also expecting their second child in March of 2018, a baby girl.  Along with this, Justin's job is the only form of income. This will be a long journey, so any donations are greatly appreciated. If you are unable to donate we ask you to lift them up in prayer for we know God will make a way. Donations are accepted here or direct through his mom's paypal via paypal.me/JillianRussell just leave a note saying it's for Jace. Thank you, The Russell Family---As of September 2018, we have updated about each of the stages he has gone through thus far, and what is to be expected from now until end of treatment.

uad896-help-jack-beat-cancer.name: Jack Corr
uad896-help-jack-beat-cancer.title: Help Jack Beat Cancer
uad896-help-jack-beat-cancer.description: This is for my sister Jessica Corr and her husband Tim and son Jack. Upon hearing the news of her family’s situation, so many people have reached out to me asking what they can do to help. My nephew Jack (who is three years old) has been diagnosed with metastatic neuroblastoma which is stage four of one of the most complex and serious childhood cancers. He is very seriously ill and currently in the ICU at Seattle Children’s hospital on high flow oxygen support and a feeding tube as tumors have taken over much of his lungs and are all throughout his abdomen. He has cancer through several different parts of his body and will need a very aggressive treatment in order to make it. Jessica is two weeks away from giving birth to their third child and Tim just returned 3 weeks ago from being deployed in Poland with the National Guard. Because Jack’s cancer is so advanced, it will take a very aggressive and long-term approach requiring the use of several different treatments including chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, immunotherapy, and a bone marrow transplant in order to fight it appropriately. His doctors estimate his treatment will take about 18 months to complete. With all of this in mind, we have estimated the cost after insurance will be about $50,000 (between medical bills and any in-home care that Jack will need as he is not doing great on his own). I also ask for your continued faith and prayers that Jack will not only make it but go onto thrive and have a great and healthy life. For those uncomfortable using go fund me (because I do know they do take a certain percentage of the funds) I will also post Jessica‘s Venmo here if people would like to donate to her directly. Thank you to all of you who are willing to help even in a small way. The emotional cost of having a child suffering from cancer and adding to it delivering a new baby is really heavy and so I am hoping that with some of their financial burden lifted it will be a little easier to bear. Thank you all for being willing to help.

aiming-to-save-a-life.name: Jamie
aiming-to-save-a-life.title: Life for Jamie
aiming-to-save-a-life.description:
I'm the grateful aunty of my 2-year-old nephew, who has just been diagnosed with a tumor in his brain called Ewing Sarcoma. This baby boy is so full of life, and now has to begin chemo/radiation treatments for this terrible illness we were told he was born with. His short little life has been nothing but horrific circumstances after horrific circumstances. This boy and his single parent, his mom, can't seem to get a break on life! Jamie (my nephew) has suffered from his father's domestic abuse, was saved multiple times by his abused mommy (thank God for her protection skills), being without a home and living in a car, to moving to Florida for safety reasons, and having their apartment (their new "safe haven") washed away by hurricanes! And once again, homeless except for life in mommy's car! Mom is not being offered employment opportunities due to the fact she is Jamie's only support system and has to work full-time! They have tried multiple ways to get financial help from the government and are told funds are backed up, minimally 8 months away... possibly longer. They have so many more struggles... too many to list.



Now on top of everything else, a diagnosis of cancer in this 2-year-old!



Asking for financial support until, hopefully, they get the situation a bit more under control. For those of you who are asking about the medical bills...



Fortunately, John Hopkins Children's Cancer in Florida will help a tremendous amount with treatments/care for Jamie... we praise God for that! And will continue our prayers. Yet a little financial stability could go a long way in so many ways for them. Up until these issues, Jamie's mom, Lexi, was working as a full-time CNA wanting to start nursing school... then the domestic abuse began and their whole world changed for the worst.



My wish is that others can open their hearts, show some compassion toward Lexi and Jamie, this story, and hopefully be able to help... even a small amount would be greatly appreciated by all of us!



Peace and love to all of you... thanks so much for your consideration towards donating.

help-jax-and-family-with-medical-expense.name: Jax
help-jax-and-family-with-medical-expense.title: Help Jax and family with medical expenses
help-jax-and-family-with-medical-expense.description: We just found out that our 3 yr old son Jax has ALL Leukemia. We need some help with medical bills and bills. We only have one income and 2 other child that still need to be cared for that cannot come here due to covid. This is going to be a long road, they say at least 2 1/2yrs of a lot of hospital trips and stays. Jax cannot leave the hospital for several weeks as of now. Anything is greatly appreciated. Thank you everyone for your support. Will update as we find out more.#Jax strong

jett-machs-medical-bills.name: Jett Mach
jett-machs-medical-bills.title: Jett Mach’s Medical Bills
jett-machs-medical-bills.description:
Disclaimer:  I have permission to do this Go Fund Me from Jett’s Parents, Chad and Jessica.   



This little full of life little boy, Jett, has been through a lot these last 2 months while Mom and Dad get to deal with the hard stuff of medical bills from all of this.   



It all started September 11, 2022 while out playing at Dropzone, a trampoline park, when Jett hit his knee to his forehead.   He then went to school and a kid swinging his back park hit Jett in the exact same spot.  It was at this point that more bruises started showing up.  



The bruise on his forehead was huge and other bruises were rapidly forming from something as simple as falling down on the ground.  His parents took him to the Emergency Room and they didn’t find anything wrong with him.    So Chad and Jessica took him down to Children’s Hospital in Omaha, NE and they found out that his platelets were so low that any other fall could have been detrimental.  They stayed at the Hospital for quite some days until the platelets came up so it was safe to take him home.  



They’ve been to Children’s so many times either staying there or in outpatients to lessen the costs.  It’s not over yet but at least he is now over 50k platelet count but normal range is above 150k so he isn’t out of the woods just yet.  



 It’s been a very grueling process and also not cheap.   I’m asking for them to help cover medical expenses.  I, Jim, Thank You for any and all donations!

baby-john-nicu-medical-expenses.name: John Jr
baby-john-nicu-medical-expenses.title: Baby John’s NICU medical expenses
baby-john-nicu-medical-expenses.description: Dear family and friends, I am raising money to help with the unexpected early arrival of my baby boy John Jr aka JJ. I was only 22 weeks pregnant when my water broke and was immediately admitted to the hospital and put on strict bed rest. I had no complications prior to my water breaking so the reason is still unknown. The goal was to stay pregnant as long as possible so the chances of him surviving would be greater. I was able to hold on for another 2 weeks but on Sunday March 10, 2019 my baby boy arrived, 4 months early by emergency c section. He was only 1lb 6oz. I was told by many doctors of all the risks of going forward with the pregnancy but my faith was strong and I knew in my heart that my baby boy belonged here. He was the gift that I’ve been waiting for my entire life. I knew that the road ahead would be tough but I was willing to do whatever it took to make sure he grew healthy and strong. We have now been in the NICU for 120 days and counting. He has come a long way but still has a ways to go, with his heart and lungs being the main focus. My baby is a true fighter and even on the days when I’m feeling overwhelmed and just worried about every little thing, he gives me this look that to me, says “mommy everything will be ok”.  I must admit, he is a lot stronger than me. After being poked & pricked, all the tubes, machines, monitors, and medications, he has proven that! And he inspires me everyday. If anyone would like to make a donation so that I can time off to care for him when he comes home and to help with the heavy medical expenses It would be greatly appreciated! ❤️❤️

support-for-baby-jjs-medical-journey.name: Jordan James Didericksen
support-for-baby-jjs-medical-journey.title: Support for Baby JJ's Medical Journey
support-for-baby-jjs-medical-journey.description:
Hello, the Didericksen family has experienced some unexpected medical problems with their newborn son Jordan James who was born just 2 days ago. What they thought was just pneumonia was actually a symptom and result of him having esophageal atresia and Tracheoesophageal fistula.



JJ hasn't been able to or interested in eating since birth. That, along with him consistently spitting up mucus and fluid, led Carlie and her husband to take him to Primary Children's Hospital. They immediately got him in and started running tests (echo, X-rays, etc.) and when they were unable to place an NG tube, they realized that his esophagus wasn't connected to his stomach.



JJ is expected to go into surgery tomorrow, June 17. A week after that, he will hopefully be able to start eating breastmilk. They have told Carlie to expect about a month stay.



We are putting together this GoFundMe to help with the expenses of the surgery/hospital stay, food while his parents are at the hospital and away from home and help with whatever else they'll need during this time.

support-keonis-fight-against-neuroblasto.name: Keoni
support-keonis-fight-against-neuroblasto.title: Support Keoni's Fight Against Neuroblastoma
support-keonis-fight-against-neuroblasto.description:
On Sunday Sept 29th, our lives forever changed. We woke up to shrill cries coming from the room of our 5-month-old baby boy. When I picked Keoni up, I noticed he was hot to touch, his right eye was drooping, and his pupils were unequal. A golf ball-sized lump on the right side of his neck was inhibiting his ability to straighten his neck. 

We went to the ER and were then told we needed to be transferred to a Children's Medical Center for a higher level of care. After an ambulance ride, blood tests, X-rays, MRIs, and days of anxiously waiting for a diagnosis, the doctor entered our room and introduced himself as the Oncologist. He told us what every parent fears hearing - "the results show your baby most likely has cancer - neuroblastoma."

Keoni's scans show he has a tumor on the right side of his neck slightly shifting his trachea, a tumor on the right side of his spine slightly shifting his lung, and multiple masses in his enlarged liver. 

We feel like we're living in a bad dream that we wish we could wake up from. A few weeks ago, Keoni was playing and laughing with his grandparents visiting from CA and TX. 

Days now are filled with doctor appointments, blood tests, biopsies, medicine, conversations about plans, updating family, and waiting for results and next steps. 

Keoni will soon undergo a surgical procedure to insert a central IV catheter in one of his major veins close to his heart for 6 to 12 weeks of chemotherapy. 

During this time, we have taken a personal leave of absence from work and are spending quality time caring for Keoni. 

Keoni's sweet smile and playful energy when he feels well give us strength for the moments he doesn't feel well, as we share hours consoling and holding him in our arms.

We are so blessed to have loving family in CA & TX and friends in NYC and beyond reaching out, checking in, and showing support. We are eternally grateful. 

We so appreciate all the offers for help and support during this difficult time as we navigate this diagnosis and treatment. 

If you feel called to offer support to help us with possible treatment options, bills, food, and travel to/from the hospital while we are caring for Keoni and not at work, we truly appreciate it. 

Or

If you work at Northwell Health, please consider donating 1 PTO day: 

Sign into MyExperience > click 'Help' tab > click 'HR Service Request' >

Click 'Create Service Request' >

in Category of Service Request, type or scroll to 'PTO Donation Form' >

in Service Request Details type 'Donating PTO to Sara Choi Person ID # 239425 for Personal Leave of Absence to care for child during illness' 

Thank you so much for all of your love, prayers, and support as we pray in hope and faith for pain relief, healing, strength and full recovery for our loving baby boy, Keoni.

emergency-medical-expenses-for-our-baby-.name: Kingstin
emergency-medical-expenses-for-our-baby-.disease: severe burns from hot oil accident
emergency-medical-expenses-for-our-baby-.title: Emergency medical expenses for our baby Kingstin.
emergency-medical-expenses-for-our-baby-.description:
Sunday started off the same as every other day, playing with the kids and spending time with the family. We were making our usual buffalo wings and getting ready to watch football when a terrible freak accident happened. 

While moving the frying oil from the stove the handle of the pan broke and the hot oil spilled. Sadly, it spilled and splashed onto and severely burned our sweet baby Kingstin. We immediately ran him under ice cold water. Once we took off his clothes, we knew right away we had to come straight to the ER. From there we were told he would need to be transferred to a burn unit (there is only 1 in the state of NJ). A few hours later we were finally where he needed to be to get the care he required.

The doctors let us know that the majority of his burns are second degree, but there was one area of his body in particular that was concerning. The care team here has been fantastic but our baby has a lot of healing to do. We will most likely be here in the burn unit for a minimum of 7-10 days. Each day he is taken into the “burn tank” where his team changes his dressings and assesses his healing and what to do next. We are still waiting to get final word on whether or not he will need any grafts.

If you don’t know about burn healing, it’s a lot of wait and see what the body can do on its own. So this is where we are now.

Mom and Dad are trying our best to keep King as comfortable as possible with lots of love and gentle snuggles. Both Nanas are doing a spectacular job helping with Ashlin and little Colin, we wouldn’t be able to get through this without them.

We are reaching out to all of you for a bit of help to offset some of the medical expenses as well as to ask that you keep King in your prayers and thoughts. We will take all the healing vibes we can get for him! He has been such a strong little guy throughout this whole process! 

Thank you all for your help, love, calls, and well wishes! He is a fighter and he is definitely #KingstinStrong!

❤️ The Senior Family

3on218w.name: Kylie Ann Pruitt
3on218w.title: Kylie's Fight Against Child Cancer
3on218w.description: "Our sweet Kylie Ann Pruitt"Kylie was born March 30, 2015. That day She changed all of our lives forever. From the first glimpse we were all so joyful with getting to finally meet her. Sara Pruitt her mother was so brave being a young mother that she was and with her husband Grant Pruitt. Kylie had a specific spot in each one of our hearts and continues to keep us here on our feet and making memories.On April 21st 2017 we found out that Kylie has a tumor which is cancerous. We are very early in the stages to see where this will lead in her early life and getting to know more about it as the days go by. There are still many test that need to be done and surgery. She will begin Chemotherapy in this next week to try and shrink the tumor so it can be removed. We do not know exactly how all of this will work or how long it will take so that we can bring our precious Kylie home where she belongs. We are asking for your prayers and your guidance through this journey with our Kylie. Campaign created by Bradley Gray

medical-expenses-for-baby-kynnidi.name: Kynnidi
medical-expenses-for-baby-kynnidi.title: Medical Expenses For Baby Kynnidi
medical-expenses-for-baby-kynnidi.description:
My name is Kynnidi, I am 10 months old. My mommy and I live in Southern Idaho. My mommy is the best mommy in the world. She works so hard for me and our dog, Dodge.  She loves me so much and she is my world.  I hurt my eye when I was playing with my toys. The doctor here said that I need to see a special doctor who works with kids my age. 



My mommy and I will be taking a road trip to Utah very soon. Mommy says that I will have to go to sleep for a while so they can take special pictures of my head and eye.  Then after that the doctor will let my mommy, and I hope me too, know what is wrong and what they can do to fix my eye.



My mommy will need to take off a lot of time from work to take care of me. We will need to travel to Utah a lot and my doggy will need someone to watch him while we are traveling too. 



My Ama said that she needed my help with this letter, and she would get the fund raiser started to help with my doctor and travel costs.



Thank you so very much for your donation to help with my medical expenses for my eye!

laeneys-medical-expenses.name: Laeney
laeneys-medical-expenses.title: Laeneys Medical Expenses
laeneys-medical-expenses.description: Laeney had her first seizure on Christmas day 2022. Her seizures have progressively gotten worse. She has had numerous ambulance rides and hospital stays. Currently her main Dr is at U of M, but we really would like to try to get her to the Mayo Clinic because nothing seems to be working at this point. She has appointments every other week at U of M right now for more testing.  We are asking for help with expenses to take some weight off the familys shoulders.  Hopefully when they can get her into the Mayo Clinic this will help cover anything they may need.   They are also looking into brain mapping which insurance does not cover.  We are desperate to try to figure out how to get Laeney back to living a normal life.  Laeney's reward after all the hospital tests and overnights is a trip to Krispy Kreme (which is where she is in this picture)  Even if you can't donate please pray for answers for Laeney.

donate-to-help-with-logans-medical-expen.name: Logan
donate-to-help-with-logans-medical-expen.title: Donate to help with Logan's medical expenses.
donate-to-help-with-logans-medical-expen.description:
If you're lucky enough to know Logan, you know he is the coolest kid with the biggest heart. He doesn't know a stranger, is the most sensitive, caring soul, and is always making everyone laugh with witty comebacks. To see him start this journey is heartbreaking, and the whole family could use prayers.



Logan, whos only 8yrs old, is currently at Children's National Hospital after a large mass, consistant with lymphoma, was found in his chest. He just had a biospy to determine specific diagnoses and the course of treatment. It's looking like Logan is in for a long journey.



Everyone has been asking how to help? Right now, the biggest blessings are prayers and the gift of time for the family to focus on Logan's healing. The family depends on survival from two small businesses, and there is no paid time off. Any help would be so greatly appreciated.

help-baby-logans-medical-expenses.name: Logan
help-baby-logans-medical-expenses.title: Help Baby Logan's Medical Expenses
help-baby-logans-medical-expenses.description: This is our son Logan.He was diagnosed with Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) while he was in utero at 29 weeks. This is a condition where an extra electrical pathway is formed when the heart is developing and causes a short circuit and the heart beats as high as 300 bpm.Mom was in the hospital for 4 days of observations and given a beta blocker to try and steady his heart rate. After repeated episodes the decision was made to perform an emergency C-Section and he was born on February 2nd at 1:21 pm weighing in at 5 lbs 6 ounces.He was immediately put on the standard drug treatments for SVT and kept in the NICU.The amazing doctors and nurses assigned to him kept doing everything they could to keep his heart rate down, but nothing worked. They tried every drug and technique to prevent his episodes and to convert him out of them. After 6 weeks he started to develop an infection that was most likely due to a lack of blood flow to his gut because his heart was pumping it through too fast.Feeds were stopped and he was put on IV nutrition.Most cases of SVT are something that children grow out of, but in cases that are severe and not managed by drugs they do a procedure called an ablation to burn off that extra pathway and restore normal heart function. This procedure is typically reserved for older kids because an infant's heart is extremely delicate.  The decision was made to do the ablation when Logan's condition continued to deteriorate.  He was spending his days in SVT and they repeatedly had to shock him with a transesophageal pacer. This is a catheter that goes up his nose and down his throat and placed just behind his heart in order to try and shock his heart into a normal rhythm. This was just as pleasant as it sounds and as effective as everything else they tried.He went in for his procedure at about 12:30 on March 31st. After some difficulty getting set up, including the central line that was placed in his scalp coming out and a new IV needing to be put in,  the electrophysiologist was moving the catheter into position to do the ablation.This is when the worst thing possible happened and the left ventricle of his heart was punctured.Logan spent 50 minutes in cardiac arrest while the team worked to open his chest and repair the hole. He's currently on an ECMO machine that does the work of his heart and lungs for him. The doctors don't know how much blood made it to his vital organs or how much damage was done.As you can imagine, expenses are adding up quickly. Please help in any way you can.

zewg7v64.name: Lucas
zewg7v64.title: Lucas' Fight Against Child Cancer
zewg7v64.description: At 8 years old, Lucas is the youngest of three boys. He always has a smile on his face and is one of the sweetest boys you’ll meet. On March 29, 2016,  Lucas was diagnosed with a very rare and aggressive cancer, Rhabdomyosarcoma. The doctors have said he will undergo months of treatment and chemotherapy. He has been given a 20-30% survival rate. He has a very large and rapidly growing tumor in his lower abdominal/ groin area and has metastisized in his bone marrowMy brother, Robert and my sister-in-law Karina, are amazing parents and both work full time to support their family. Like a lot of families, they live pay check to pay check. Robert is a self-employed piano tuner and does well supporting his family, but unfortunately does not have any benefits for time off to take care of his son. His wife also does not have any paid time off during treatment.  This is where family, friends, and community steps in. As his brother, I want to help relieve the financial anxiety of raising a family and travel costs for chemo. Please help my brother and his family in their courageous fight against cancer. Every little bit will help. Thank you from the bottom of my heart!**I will be updating this page as more information comes in on treatment details.** You can also follow his facebook at https://www.facebook.com/LoveforLukiWill Jones

ce78k-mackenzies-medical-expenses.name: Mackenzie
ce78k-mackenzies-medical-expenses.disease: second degree and third degree burns on hands, arms and legs
ce78k-mackenzies-medical-expenses.title: Mackenzie’s medical expenses
ce78k-mackenzies-medical-expenses.description: Saturday around 7pm, my sweet baby, Mackenzie was seriously injured and had to be rushed to Westchester Medical Center, where she will stay for the next few weeks. We were at a family function where hot coals weren’t properly disposed of on gravel (which disguised the coals) in close proximity where the children were playing. Mackenzie, Allie and daddy were playing catch with a cardboard box, (Let’s face it kids rather play with boxes, than toys) After 10 minutes of playing and having a blast, Mackenzie went running for the box, in of course her rain boots, which caused her to fall on the hidden hot coals.  I thank god that Jesse was very close to her and was able to react fast. But the damage was already done. Mackenzie sustained deep second degree and third degree burns on her hands, arms and legs. Her rain boots protected her feet and ankles. Tomorrow morning, she will be heading into surgery for skin graphs and most likely a feed tube. The feed tube is because the best thing for burn victims is a high calorie and high protein diet to stimulate skin regrowth. We are forever grateful for whatever donations and help we receive and if you can’t donate please just say a pray for our baby girl.

baby-masons-medical-fund-helping-roy-and.name: Mason
baby-masons-medical-fund-helping-roy-and.title: Baby Mason’s Medical Fund  Helping Roy and Haley
baby-masons-medical-fund-helping-roy-and.description:
Updates are at the bottom. 





Roy and Haley have been excited to welcome their baby (Mason) into this world. At twenty weeks it was found that Mason had pulmonary atresia. Then at thirty one weeks Haley started having preeclampsia. Haley missed a lot of work. She was on bed rest for two months. At thirty five weeks Haley was admitted into the hospital. With his known heart issue the doctors were hoping he would not come until 7/26. Mason weighed 5 pounds 4 oz and was taken to Children's within an hour of being born. Unfortunately he had to be intubated and due to the stress on his little body he is on lots of meds. He is due to have the balloon surgery 7/22 but one of his lungs are not working so they are doing a CT scan and doing another Nuero check. He will also need a stent surgery within a week. It is $10 a day to park at Children’s. Haley can eat for free but Roy has to pay for all his meals. Roy, Haley and Mason are going to need all the support they can get. They have a very long road ahead of them. Haley will need to return back to work in eight short weeks unless she can afford to take FMLA and stay home a little longer. Medical expenses are going to be a lot over the next several years. They have insurance but it doesn’t cover everything at 100%. If you can give please do but if you can’t please know your prayers, text and love means so much to Roy and Haley. They want to THANK everyone from the bottom of their hearts. Right now Mason’s health is Roy and Haley’s main focus. If they don’t respond or answer please know they feel your love and are grateful for it. #TeamMason #Fighting4Mason #Praying4Mason





















Please help us share this. 





















Before birth it was discovered Mason would need a pulmonary atresia repair surgery within his first week of life and possibly three surgeries by the age of three.





















Pulmonary atresia is a birth defect (pronounced PULL-mun-airy ah-TREE-sha) of the heart where the valve that controls blood flow from the heart to the lungs doesn't form at all. In babies with this defect, blood has trouble flowing to the lungs to pick up oxygen for the body.



















7/25 Today is a big and exciting day. Mason will have his heart balloon at 1. Please join us in praying for him and his medical team. 
















Update: Unfortunate news, the procedure has been moved once again. There's another case going on before his in the cath lab today and there's been a complication. While we are disappointed that our Mason won't be getting his procedure today. 

Masons procedure will be taking place tomorrow morning around 8:30 so he will be first. And there should be little reason for any further delay.  













7/26 Mason is out of his procedure, he did amazingly! If the ballon takes(which they think it will) he won’t need a stent next week! 










7/27 A couple hours after his procedure Mason started  bleeding very badly last night in his groin where they went in. The DRs held pressure on the site for over an hour and it finally stopped bleeding. He had to receive  blood due to this. His heart rate was very high and BP was very low. They gave him a ton of meds to help his heart rate & BP. He is currently not bleeding and heart rate and blood pressure are stable. Hoping he can get weaned off some medication today.












7/31 Sweet mason 

He’s had a rough couple of days, he’s more awake and is getting agitated very easily. I know he is so tired of this breathing tube. Looks like he is going to need the stent afterwards, we will know more in the next couple of days. 
Tomrrow is a big day for him, he is getting a pic line because his ivs keep going bad and he’s just getting poked too much! He is also probably going to get a NG tube tomorrow (feeding tube) so he can start finally having some of mommas breast milk! 

I love you sweet boy. Haley 




8/5

Masons PDA has finally closed enough for him to get the stent! He is scheduled for procedure number two tomorrow afternoon. Prayers that all goes smoothly & he doesn’t bleed a lot like he did with his first procedure. 

He was also able to finally receive some breast milk!  

We are so thankful to everyone at Children’s-Dallas! From the DRs, nurses, respiratory therapist, techs, PT, OT and speech therapy. Everyone has been so amazing to Mason, Roy and I. Literally all angels  

I love you bubba, you got this!

g5vsnh-support-baby-masons-medical-journ.name: Mason Stevenson
g5vsnh-support-baby-masons-medical-journ.disease: Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome), tracheal anomalies, partially collapsed trachea and lung
g5vsnh-support-baby-masons-medical-journ.title: Support Baby Mason's Medical Journey
g5vsnh-support-baby-masons-medical-journ.description:
Sweet baby Mason Stevenson was born on June 12, 2025, and after a long stay in the NICU, finally came home on July 17. Mason was born with Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome) and has already shown incredible strength in his short life.







Recently, Mason began having trouble breathing and choking. After a visit to his pediatrician on October 17, he was transferred to Brenner Children’s Hospital, where doctors discovered tracheal anomalies — his trachea never fully developed and is partially collapsed, along with part of his lung.







On October 31, Mason will undergo major surgery for a tracheostomy, ventilator placement, and a penis reconstructive procedure. His recovery will require a lengthy hospital stay, possibly until December or January. Once home, Mason will need round-the-clock care from at least two caregivers, as well as special equipment, and modifications to the home and vehicle.







During this time, Mason’s mom, Heather Durden, will be out of work to care for her baby. This GoFundMe is set up to help the family with medical-related expenses, travel costs, meals, and monthly bills as they navigate this challenging journey.







Please consider donating and sharing to support this loving family — and most importantly, keep baby Mason and his caregivers in your prayers.

support-my-sons-family-through-their-med.name: Mateo
support-my-sons-family-through-their-med.title: Baby Mateo’s medical crisis!
support-my-sons-family-through-their-med.description:
Hi, I'm grandma Melanie.



I’m raising money for my grandson’s medical bills. 



Mateo had a symptomless infection aside from blood in his urine. It ended up traveling and turning into bacterial meningitis and now will have to be admitted for 21 days for IV antibiotics!





Not only do they have their medical bills for the unplanned c-section, but this unexpected length of stay for my grandson will be a hefty bill (out of pocket expenses) for his thorough recovery!

bjfz3-maxs-medical-bills.name: Max
bjfz3-maxs-medical-bills.title: Baby Max’s Medical Bills
bjfz3-maxs-medical-bills.description:
Baby Max is 3 months old and got a cold his first week in daycare. Within 12 hours our sweet happy baby went from having a simple dry cough to not being able to breathe on his own. He has been diagnosed with bronchiolitis and we are now on Day 3 in the Pediatric ICU at Children's Healthcare of Atlanta Scottish Rite.





Max has a feeding tube, an IV, breathing treatments and constant suctioning. He is also on a RAM nasal cannula with a ventilator attached to push the air better into his lungs since his airways are so inflamed. We have had to go up on his breathing support multiple times already and Max's medical team says we are definitely not over the worst of it yet!






Nathan and I are taking turns being by his bedside and don't know how long we will need to be taking a leave of absence from work. We have a high deductible on our insurance and honestly can't even think about the total of Max's medical bills. Nathan owns his own business and I had just returned from medical leave for Max's birth. Like so many other people who have been in our situation we know we can't face this on our own and need to ask for financial help. Any amount is appreciated. 






Thank you to everyone who has shown their love and support for Max, Nathan and I (Nicky) these last few days. We will try to update you on Max's condition!

micahs-chubbies-medical-expenses.name: Micah Perez
micahs-chubbies-medical-expenses.title: Micah’s (Chubbies) Medical Expenses
micahs-chubbies-medical-expenses.description:
Hello we are Micah’s parents Irvin and Jude Perez. Micah also known as Chubbies is our youngest child from 3 boys, very energetic and just being a happy boy.


On November 23, 2020 my son Chubbies was diagnosed with Cancer (Leukemia) which is cancer in the blood system. Since then we have received enormous amounts of support from our families, close friends and excellent coworkers in which we are very grateful for. Unfortunately we have exhausted all of our savings since November till now and we still need to continue to drive 2 hours one way to San Diego and 2 hours back to the Imperial Valley. 


The donations will mainly be used for room and lodging, food and gas for the upcoming medical travels and medical services that will be paid. We feel so grateful for the help we have received from everyone and we will forever pay it forward. Help chubbies to continue his journey to recovery. 


Thank you for your time.

mjs-fight-against-bone-cancer.name: MJ Graves
mjs-fight-against-bone-cancer.title: MJ's Fight Against Ewing’s Sarcoma
mjs-fight-against-bone-cancer.description: Dear friends and family - we're reaching out to ask for your support for our beloved friends Becky, Mike and MJ Graves. These last few months have been nothing less than a parent's worst nightmare. Mike & Becky's only child MJ was just diagnosed with bone cancer. This comes shortly after Becky was let go from her job of 19+years, leaving them to solely rely on Cobra Insurance Coverage that ends in 16 months time and runs $2200 a month. No parent should ever have to worry about the cost of their child's medical expenses. We would like Becky and Mike to be able to concentrate 100% on MJ and his needs by easing some of the financial burden. Many people have asked how they can help. The best way to help at this time is by making a donation. Any amount will be greatly appreciated. We would also like to ask you to share this page with your family and friends...church groups, etc. Becky & Mike are the kind of people who will go out of their way to help friends and strangers alike. Let's join together and be there for Becky, Mike and MJ. ￼MJ's Last Few Months (shared by his mom Becky) In mid/late October 2017 MJ was experiencing pain in his thigh that got progressively worse throughout each day and then started fresh the next morning. Eventually it reached the point that even when lying down, he was in excruciating pain - literally screaming. That night even though we felt silly we took him to a standalone ER for thigh pain. I told her that he had a fever before we came if that was relevant and she said he did not have a fever, that body temp goes up at night. They moved his hip around, did an X-ray, and reported that they couldn't see any issues causing the pain. They offered a CT scan and blood work but said the CT scan would be a lot of radiation and if it were something that would be caught on a CT scan there would be other symptoms. So we agreed not to do the CT scan but I requested blood work. The doctor said that if we weren't doing to CT Scan there was no reason to do blood work. So we were released and told to follow up with our pediatrician, which we did the next day. Our pediatrician checked MJ over and since she didn't find anything concerning she ruled the problem to be small muscle tears. She told him to take it easy. The pain did pass in a few days, for about a week, but then returned. We called the pediatrician who referred us to an orthopedic doctor. The ortho moved him around, took an X-ray, and said it happened because he needed to stretch before physical activities, and diagnosed him with tendinitis of the knee (yes knee?). After a week or two of no improvement and in fact worse pain, and after multiple calls to the ortho asking if they were sure, they referred us to physical therapy. We owe so much to the physical therapist. It was fairly obvious to me that she knew something more serious was wrong throughout her examination. When she finished her evaluation she tactfully told us that there was something more going on and that we needed to go back to our doctors for more scans and blood work. So the next day she called the ortho for us and we called the pediatrician. We went to three appointments that day. Pediatrician, blood work (ordered by pediatrician), and the ortho. The ortho took another X-ray, charged me for my visit (yes I'm bitter) and told me he wasn't qualified to help us because he saw nothing wrong and 'sees kids who have sports injuries'. So he referred us to a better ortho - the best pediatric ortho in Dallas. The new ortho got us in the next day (Friday). He ordered an MRI which we had Saturday and he reviewed it over the weekend. He called Sunday night and told us MJ had infection in his pelvic bone and that he would need to operate within the week. He operated the first time on 12/20 (Wednesday). They took cultures but nothing (no bacteria) ever grew in the lab. MJ slowly improved following surgery, but 10 days later (12/30) he had a night of terrible pain that woke him from sleep and couldn't be managed. We were out of town so went to an ER under our Ortho's instruction and had blood work and an ultrasound. Blood work hadn't improved so they changed our oral antibiotic but ultrasound looked normal. MJ started using his crutches 100% of the time and after not using the leg for a week or so it felt a little better but if he moved to much it resulted in hours of crying. Still nothing growing in the lab. After returning home we had a follow up appointment and did blood work to check infection markers - they were WORSE not better. So the doctor ordered another MRI which we did the next afternoon. The doctor called about 2 hours after the MRI to tell us the infection in the pelvic bone was worse/bigger than when he operated. We had to go back into the operating room for the same procedure THAT NIGHT. It was much more aggressive/invasive and he was in a lot of pain. They took more cultures but again, nothing grew in the lab. They put in a PICC line so he could get IV antibiotics at the hospital and then eventually at home for 6 weeks. Unfortunately a couple days later he was back in terrible pain in his thigh that caused moaning and screaming for long periods of time. Another MRI showed that he had infection/an abscess in his right thigh. Enter his 3rd surgery in a month on 1/20. More fluid taken for culture, but again nothing grew in the lab. Walking was limited to 25-50 steps and every time he got out of bed it resulted in an hour or more of terrible pain. He got mildly better and we were released on Wednesday 1/24 to home health. Home was hard too. He might be fine for hours but if he had to crutch-it to the bathroom it would result in hours of writhing in pain and often fever. Tuesday 1/30 returned disappointing blood work and Wednesday 1/31 we had another MRI. The next day we had a follow up appointment at his office. When he came in MJ was on the table crying in pain. He asked us to come back into the hospital to operate in the pelvic bone again. MJs 4th surgery was 2/1. They took a ton of bone and fluid and tissue so that they could rule things out and hopefully finally identify the root cause. MJ continued to have terrible pain. We all thought it was from the surgery but it got worse not better. His pain in his thigh was/is unbearable. They went through all the most powerful pain medications and nothing worked for more than a few minutes. He can't walk and can barely stand. And now I come to (believe it or not) the worst part of MJs tale. The surgeon came to us last night (2/5) and asked if we wanted him to speak in front of MJ or in private. I already knew the news would be unbearable. He started with the fact that there was more/new infection in the right thigh and some also in the left visible from yet another MRI that morning. He would probably have to operate again. But he hadn't gotten to the worst part. The pathology lab had returned results. Yes they saw inflammation in the bone (indicating infection), but also "Small round blue cell tumor" cells. We don't get know for sure which 'flavor' of cancer (yes, I just said that MJ has cancer). Our amazing orthopedic surgeon thinks it is one from a short list: Lymphoma of bone, Ewing's sarcoma, or PNET. He said it's aggressive, and its life threatening. And we can assume that if he had these cells in his pelvic bone that they are in all of his bones. We are moving to a Dallas hospital with an oncology department in the morning, and plan to get a second opinion regarding the plan to heal him either in Houston or New York. It's our understanding that for this rare form of cancer those are the most qualified hospitals. And tonight we tell our 12 year old that he has cancer.

9z58j-natalies-medical-expenses.name: Natalie
9z58j-natalies-medical-expenses.title: Natalie’s Medical expenses
9z58j-natalies-medical-expenses.description:
Help Natalie Get the Care She Needs



Our sweet Natalie has been facing ongoing health challenges, and she now needs an important biopsy procedure to guide her treatment. The medical expenses are overwhelming, and we are reaching out for help from our community and kind-hearted donors.

Natalie is a bright and resilient child. Despite her struggles, she keeps her spirit shining! She deserves the chance to focus on healing and being a kid, not on medical worries.



Fundraising Goal: $19,200

We are raising $19,200 to cover Natalie’s biopsy procedure and related medical expenses. After GoFundMe processing fees, this will provide the $18,500 needed to give her the care she requires.



Every donation, no matter the size, helps us get closer to this goal and makes a real difference in Natalie’s health and recovery. If you are able, please consider donating or sharing this fundraiser with others. Your support means the world to us and will make a direct impact in Natalie’s journey toward better health.



From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for supporting Natalie.

nikos-type-1-diabetes-medical-expenses.name: Niko
nikos-type-1-diabetes-medical-expenses.title: Niko’s Type 1 Diabetes Medical Expenses
nikos-type-1-diabetes-medical-expenses.description:
Meet Niko! 

Niko is one of the coolest 6 year olds there is. My family had the honor of meeting 

Niko and his family through baseball. We all became fast friends.  Niko’s biggest passion is baseball! He’s a Braves fan and he plays travel ball for the 7U team in our town.  His nickname is Niko Chico Baseball Man, that’s how much he loves the sport!

At a double header on Sunday Niko started feeling a little funky and asked the coach to sit out a few innings. Nearing the end of the first game he came and sat with his mom and decided he still wasn’t feeling well enough to play the second game-when he says no to baseball you know something isn’t right. During the second game he fell asleep on his mom and he didn’t play with the other kids at the pizza party after the games.

That evening after Niko still wasn’t feeling great his mom and dad took him to the ER. That’s when their family’s whole life changed. Niko was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes and transferred to the children’s hospital for care.  He will now have to change his life to watch everything he eats and drinks, constantly monitor his blood sugar and give himself insulin.

The medical bills are just starting. Insurance barely puts a dent in some of the drug costs and in some cases they need 2 monitors or 2 life savings pens-1 for home and 1 for school. 

I’m asking because my dear friends would never ask-they would keep moving forward and quietly suffer, if you can give anything at all, please consider this. All funds raised would go to Niko’s medical expenses.

Thank you so much!

#NikoChicoBaseballMan

support-for-lexi-and-norastarrs-medical-.name: Nora Starr
support-for-lexi-and-norastarrs-medical-.title: Support for Lexi and Nora-Starr's Medical Journeys
support-for-lexi-and-norastarrs-medical-.description:
Lexi’s baby girl, Nora Starr, was born very premature at just one and a half pounds and is now facing serious lung disease. This tiny warrior is fighting so hard, and Lexi is spending every moment she can by her side while trying to handle the overwhelming emotional and financial strain that comes with a long NICU stay. 

If you are able, please consider helping Lexi and baby Nora by donating or sharing their GoFundMe. Your support will go toward medical expenses, time lost from work, transportation, as she is in desperate need of a car and the many unexpected costs that come with caring for a medically fragile preemie. Even the smallest gift and a simple share can make a huge difference for them right now.

Here is the link to help:  
 https://gofund.me/5eda77d95

If you can’t donate, please keep Nora Starr and Lexi in your prayers and share this so their story reaches more people. Thank you for lifting up this young mama and her tiny, brave girl during the hardest fight of their lives.

help-baby-owen-through-cancer-treatment.name: Owen
help-baby-owen-through-cancer-treatment.title: Help Baby Owen Through Cancer Treatment
help-baby-owen-through-cancer-treatment.description:
Hi, my name is Owen. Some call me Baby Owen, like my big sister Riley. I am 9 months old, and I just found out I have Ewing Sarcoma in my spine. It is a rare form of cancer found in kids.



My mom and dad need to be here in the hospital with me, so they are unable to go to work. Mommy and daddy will have to bring me back here every 14 days for chemo treatment. If you would like to donate to help pay for expenses, my family and I would greatly appreciate it.



I will continue to update you on my progress. Please pray or send good vibes my way.



Thank you!

peters-journey-medical-expenses.name: Peter
peters-journey-medical-expenses.disease: Blue Rubber Bleb Nevus Syndrome, Venus Malformation, congenital scoliosis, kyphosis, spine and chest wall deformities
peters-journey-medical-expenses.title: Peter’s journey - medical expenses
peters-journey-medical-expenses.description:
On May 17th, 2019 we were blessed with the most beautiful & perfect baby boy, but we were not prepared to have our entire world changed. Our sweet boy was born into this world with the surprise of a lot of medical challenges. Peter is the baby of a large blended family, and he is loved so very much! He is perfect in every way. He has the most beautiful blue eyes & the sweetest smile. Unfortunately he was born with a long list of diagnosis, the most rare one being Blue Rubber Bleb Nevus Syndrome. He was also born with a 1.5 lb. Venus Malformation (VM) on his back over his spine. This malformation grew with him in the womb, and crazy enough was missed in all the ultrasounds during pregnancy. So you can only imagine how we were in shock when our beautiful baby boy was born with this tremendous mass on his back. This VM caused a lot of medical issues & concerns. We were able to get in contact with Peter’s amazing specialist Dr. Johnson who specializes in vascular anomalies. At 2 months old, Peter had it removed by an amazing team of doctors, they were able to resect 90% of the mass. This incredible team was put together by Dr. Johnson, at Nemours in Orlando. Surgery went amazing! God is good! Well, after his surgery we knew that we needed to keep an eye on his spine, Peter was born with spine and chest wall deformities. These deformities caused congenital scoliosis & kyphosis due to his spine growing around the large mass in the womb. Also due to these deformities, Peter’s breathing is very different than any other baby; Another thing we have to keep a very close eye on. All of his doctors were hoping the spine would straighten out after surgery since most of the mass was removed. However, this has not been the case, it’s actually so much worse than they expected. This is now becoming Peter’s main concern.About 2 months after surgery we went into a follow up for new updated imaging of his spine and the doctors were shocked and really didn’t know what to do. Peter’s kyphosis progressed rapidly. The curve was at 90 degrees. This is very severe for a little baby like him. Peter does not sit up, roll over or kick his legs and the doctors believe it’s due to his spine and that the spinal cord being so stretched out where the kyphosis curve and mass are sitting. We have gone to all the top orthopedic surgeons in Florida and they all are at a loss because it’s nearly impossible to perform the surgery that he needs bc of just how little he is. You see, we are also battling the fact that Peter is struggling to gain weight. We have tried all different types of formulas and his weight gain is just at a stand still. A lot of Peter’s specialists have reached out to CHOP (Children’s hospital of Philadelphia) and Boston Children’s to get their recommendations. They have the top specialists for what Peter is needing right now and they may be the only hope to helping our sweet boy have a chance of getting his spinal deformity under control before it gets any worse. Which is why his current specialists want him seen ASAP at one of those hospitals. There is no multidisciplinary children’s hospital in our state (Florida) that specialize in Peter’s medical issues. We have been told by all the doctors we have seen that their fear is if it gets any worse he can become permanently paralyzed.As his parents, we are at the point we will do anything we need to to make sure our little blessing gets the chance to have the fullest life he possibly can. If that means getting him to the right doctors and hospitals then that’s what we will do. Unfortunately, it comes with a very hefty price tag that we just can’t afford. Just the consults with the specialists that Peter needs to see is sitting around $37,000 for each specialist at each hospital. Then comes the medical treatments which will be in the hundred thousands. We are fighting the best we can with insurance to approve everything but its been a lot of going back and forth with them & it doesn’t go very quick. Unfortunately, time is not on our side and we can no longer wait on them to make a decision. We also do not know what treatments & doctors they are even going to approve if any. We are trusting in The Lord to open the doors to the specialists and hospitals that our sweet boy needs to be seen at and to open up the means for us to be able to afford to get him there. So many people have reached out asking how they can help and of course first and foremost is prayers! But we also thought we would set this fundraiser up for Peter. All the money from here will go to 1st getting him to the specialists at Boston Children’s and CHOP that are requesting to see him. Covering all doctors fees, hospital fees, imaging and any testing and procedures.  Traveling to and from the hospitals and home. Helping to cover costs of time off work during these times. Next, the money would go to all medical testings, equipment, procedures, medicines, therapies that are not covered by his insurance. We thank each and everyone of you that have supported our sweet boy through his journey and that have been there for our family in this very challenging time. We love you all!!


**Here is one of his most recent xrays showing a side view of his kyphosis.

baby-peyton-needs-our-help-beating-cance.name: Peyton
baby-peyton-needs-our-help-beating-cance.title: Baby Peyton Needs Our Help Beating Cancer!
baby-peyton-needs-our-help-beating-cance.description:
Our beloved Peyton was recently diagnosed with a rare form of cancer: advanced stage 4, metastatic neuroblastoma. As part of his extended family, we were shocked, devastated, and left wondering, "What can we do to help?" Please join us in our effort to provide financial assistance to Lauren and Roberto, Peyton's mommy and daddy, so they can solely focus on Peyton and his full recovery. Below is a little about Peyton and his diagnosis...

Peyton, like most 2-year-olds, loves to play and has energy for days! His smile lights up any room and you can't help but laugh along with him - his laughter is that infectious! He loves sports and you can usually find him carrying around a ball of some sort. He likes putting together puzzles and counting. He also loves animals, especially his black lab Maddison. Most recently, Peyton began learning about dinosaurs and seems to really enjoy those too!

A couple of weeks ago, Lauren and Roberto noticed Peyton limping on his left leg. Because they hadn't seen him trip or fall, they decided to wait a day or two but when he didn't show improvement, they took him to the doctor. About a week and several invasive procedures later, we're now faced with the scary diagnosis facing our sweet boy! Peyton will start chemotherapy in the forthcoming days and his continuing treatment will be determined based on how he responds to chemo. We will update this GoFundMe page when we have news to share, so feel free to follow it for updates.

As Lauren, Peyton's mommy, explained to us, "For the last 2 weeks we have been living every parent's worst nightmare... We aren't asking for your pity or sympathy - all we ask is for prayers. We do believe in the power of prayer. WE WILL FIGHT THIS CANCER! I beg you all to take a minute or two out of your day and pray for Peyton. Pray for his peace, comfort, and cure."

At times like these, parents want to be by their ailing child's side. Please help us alleviate some of their stress by donating to this worthwhile cause. Any amount you are able to donate will go towards medical bills, medical supplies, and general costs.

Peyton is our beloved son, grandson, and nephew and it is with love, humility, and the most gracious hearts that we ask for your financial assistance and prayers during this difficult time.



To learn more about neuroblastoma please visit the following sites:

https://www.stjude.org/disease/neuroblastoma.html

https://www.cancer.org/cancer/neuroblastoma/about/what-is-neuroblastoma.html



TRANSLATED IN SPANISH BELOW:

Nuestro amado Peyton recientemente fue diagnosticado con un cáncer poco común: se trata de neuroblastoma metastásico avanzado (estadio 4). Como integrantes de su familia extendida, nos sentimos devastados y hemos pensado en la mejor forma para ayudar. Es por esto que iniciamos un GoFundMe. Pueden unirse a nuestra recaudación que busca brindar alivio económico a Lauren y Roberto, los padres de Peyton, para que logren enfocarse en el cuido de Peyton y su recuperación. Abajo explicamos un poco sobre Peyton y su diagnóstico.



¡Peyton, como la mayoría de niños de 2 años, ama jugar y tiene muchísima energía! Su sonrisa es preciosa y puede iluminar toda la habitación. Disfrutamos especialmente cuando se ríe, porque lo hace de forma tan contagiosa que todos terminan uniéndose. Le encantan los deportes y suele ir de un lado a otro con sus balones de juguete. Además está aprendiendo a contar y disfruta de armar rompecabezas. Es amante de los animales, especialmente Maddison, la perra labrador de su familia. Recientemente, Peyton descubrió los dinosaurios y se encuentra muy entusiasmado aprendiendo acerca de estos.



Hace unas semanas, Lauren y Roberto observaron a Peyton cojeando de su pierna izquierda. Como no se había golpeado ni sufrido caídas, decidieron esperar un par de días. Sin embargo, no hubo mejoría en los síntomas por lo que acudieron al médico. Después de varios estudios de imágenes y procedimientos invasivos, nos dieron a conocer el aterrador diagnóstico que enfrenta nuestro amado Peyton. Sin tiempo que perder, en los próximos días iniciará tratamiento con quimioterapia, y según la respuesta inicial a las primeras sesiones de quimioterapia, se determinará los siguientes tratamientos (cirugía, radioterapia, trasplante de médula ósea...). Estaremos actualizando esta página de GoFundMe, por lo que los invitamos a seguirla para conocer noticias y actualizaciones sobre Peyton.



En palabras de Lauren, la mamá de Peyton: "En las últimas dos semanas hemos vivido la peor pesadilla de todo padre... No estamos pidiendo por su lástima ni simpatía, solamente pedimos por sus oraciones. Nosotros creemos en el poder de la oración. ¡VAMOS A LUCHAR CONTRA ESTE CÁNCER! Les ruego a todos que tomen uno o dos minutos de su día y oren por Peyton. Oren por su paz, consuelo y cura".



En situaciones como esta, los padres desean estar al lado de su hijo enfermo. ¡Ayudanos a aliviar la preocupación de su familia donando a esta causa, sin importar el monto! Todos los fondos recaudados serán destinados al pago de facturas del hospital, equipo médico, y gastos generales.



Peyton es nuestro amado hijo, nieto, sobrino y primo... Por lo que con el corazón lleno de amor, humildad y misericordia, solicitamos tu ayuda financiera y oraciones durante estos tiempos difíciles.



Para conocer más acerca neuroblastoma podés consultar los siguientes links:

https://www.cancer.org/es/cancer/neuroblastoma/si-su-hijo-tiene-un-neuroblastoma.html

https://www.stjude.org/es/cuidado-tratamiento/enfermedades-que-tratamos/neuroblastoma.html

help-with-costs-of-presleys-medical-care.name: Presley
help-with-costs-of-presleys-medical-care.title: Help with cost of brain tumor medical expenses
help-with-costs-of-presleys-medical-care.description: We are trying to raise money for Presleys medicines and appointments until her insurance becomes effective again. We also need help getting lots of work on our car to be able to go back and forth from McMinnville to Nashville and other areas. We also don’t know how long our hospital stay will be when surgery is done so it would also help us with any expenses for that. She has a brain tumor that will have to be removed to see exactly what it is. They don’t think it’s cancer but we can’t rule it out just yet. The medicines are for her seizures to help control them until surgery can happen. We appreciate anything and everything.

help-with-baby-prestons-medical-fund.name: Preston Kendall
help-with-baby-prestons-medical-fund.title: Help with Baby Preston’s Medical Fund
help-with-baby-prestons-medical-fund.description:
On October 18, 2022, my baby cousin, Preston Kendall, was born. Shortly after birth, he began experiencing eating problems. Two days later, his conditions severely worsened and he was flown in a helicopter from Fort Mohave, Arizona to the children’s hospital in Las Vegas, Nevada. After spending two weeks in the NICU, he was diagnosed with a rare disease that only affects 1 in every 5,000 babies. This disease is called Hirschsprung’s disease, a disease that affects the colon and large intestine, with the the only fix being surgery. Preston will be affected by this disease for the rest of his life, but surgery can alleviate many symptoms.

Preston’s surgery will be on January 26th, 2023 in Phoenix, Arizona. This is four hours away from his home. Preston and his family will have to spend a total of 2 weeks in Phoenix for this surgery. Then, they will have to travel to Phoenix for the next 6-12  months 1-2 times a month to meet with his surgeon, following the surgery.I would love to help my baby cousin and family in anyway possible, so I am setting this go fund me to assist with not only the unexpected medical bills associated with the NICU stay, helicopter ride, surgery, and surgery appointments, but also the costs of constant travel every month. This is especially important because his parents have run out of paid time off due to the unexpected hospital time for baby Preston and still have so much more time to take off for him. Preston is the sweetest, smiliest, and happiest baby who adores his big brother, Jack. He also loves babbling to his loving mom and dad. Anything and everything helps for my cousin, Preston. Thank you. All my love,
Christy Stopher

help-kaitlyn-and-rhodes-fight-rare-tumor.name: Rhodes
help-kaitlyn-and-rhodes-fight-rare-tumor.title: Help Kaitlyn and Rhodes Fight Rare Tumor
help-kaitlyn-and-rhodes-fight-rare-tumor.description:
Help Support Baby Rhodes and Kaitlyn Through Cancer Treatment



In March, our sweet baby Rhodes celebrated his first birthday. Shortly after, our family received heartbreaking news: Rhodes has been diagnosed with a liver tumor consistent with Hepatoblastoma, a rare form of liver cancer. On May 5th, Rhodes will undergo major surgery to remove the tumor, followed by several rounds of chemotherapy at Lurie Children’s Hospital in Chicago.



This has been an overwhelming and emotional time for my sister and our family as we navigate the challenges of caring for baby Rhodes while managing the significant financial burden that comes with his treatment. We are hoping to raise $20,000 to help cover the costs of surgery, ongoing chemotherapy, travel, and related medical expenses.



Your support—whether through a donation or by sharing this page—means the world to us. Every little bit helps as we rally around Rhodes and give him the strength and resources he needs to fight this battle.



Thank you for your love, support, and prayers.

support-for-baby-ryland.name: Ryland
support-for-baby-ryland.title: Support for Baby Ryland
support-for-baby-ryland.description:
This is helping Keaton, Kayla, and baby Ryland. As they travel back and forth to children’s, medical expenses, and time off work. 



He was born on August 14,2025 via emergency c section. There were some complications that have put him in children’s hospital for a while. We’re so thankful for all of the prayers and love sent our way. We ask that you continue all the prayers as we can see and feel the difference they’ve made!

sebastian039s-fight-with-stage-4-childho.name: Sebastian Llanes
sebastian039s-fight-with-stage-4-childho.title: Sebastian's Fight with Childhood Cancer
sebastian039s-fight-with-stage-4-childho.description: Isn't it crazy to think that, although 'death' is the only thing we are certain of in life... for some reason, there is absolutely no way for us to truly prepare for when a loved one passes. Even more so, for the passing of a child.  When Sebastian Llanes, my 2-year-old cousin, was diagnosed with Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma at 9-months-old my family and I were heartbroken by the news. Nonetheless, we remained hopeful and positive for Sebastian.While Sebastian fought a good fight and had been through much more in the past two years than what most people go through in one lifetime, Sebastian laid to rest on May 14, 2019. Despite the unfortunate cards Sebastian had been given, Sebastian was a loving, smart, courageous, brave, and above all things STRONG...  a VERY VERY VERY STRONG boy. Despite all the surgeries, ICU stays, MRI’s, X-Ray’s, multiple medications, sleepless nights, pain, and confusion, Sebastian continued to be the unique and incredible little guy that he was. He loved monster trucks, milkshakes, Doritos, cuddling with his stuffed animals, YouTube videos, and getting hugs and kisses from his incredibly supportive and hard working parents, Bryan and Nikki. Despite all that Sebastian had been through, he continued to be a happy and joyful boy, even during the most difficult times.Bryan and Nikki had been nothing but the BEST PARENTS to Sebastian. All of Bryan and Nikki’s efforts, energy, and time these past 2 years had been devoted to giving Sebastian the best life they can give him. The incredible unconditional love they had for their only child did not go unnoticed. My purpose for this GoFundMe page is to show Bryan and Nikki the same love and support they gave Sebastian. My purpose for this is to give those who have expressed the desire in helping the Llanes family an opportunity to do so, no matter how big or small. My purpose for all of this is to give Bryan and Nikki the support and love they need during this incredibly difficult time in their lives. *All funds will go directly to the Llanes family to assist with past medical, funeral, and living expenses. Prayers, positive thoughts, and lots of love are also and always greatly appreciated. * THANK YOU &I APPRECIATE EACH AND EVERYONE OF YOU FOR TAKING THE TIME TO VISIT THIS PAGE AND FOR YOUR GENEROSITY.

help-to-support-medical-expenses.name: Shifa Fatima
help-to-support-medical-expenses.title: Help to Support Medical Expenses
help-to-support-medical-expenses.description: Friends this is not a Fake posting.  One of my friends sister's daughter is hospitalized and undergoing a medical treatment. From what I understood is kids family isn't financially strong enough to payoff the medical bills & to continue with the treatment.  They are seeking a financial help.Please consider contributing to this Go Fund Me to help this little Kid and her family..Please note that any donations are completely voluntary and any contributions would be a tremendous help. Kids Name :Shifa FatimaShe is undergoing Tuberculosis treatment in Niloufer Hospital - Ward Unit 3 ERS for last 3 weeks.GOFUNDME asked that I update my story with some information: My name is Vijay Jaladi and I'm from Bay Area, California. I set up this account to help my friends family & I will be withdrawing the funds and transfer funds to my friends Bank Account in India once this campaign is over. Thank you.

baby-sulleys-medical-expenses.name: Sulley Deshazo
baby-sulleys-medical-expenses.title: Baby Sulley's Medical Expenses
baby-sulleys-medical-expenses.description: I made this profile for my dear friends because their humble pride would not allow them to ask for help themselves. Their sweet baby Sulley has earned quite a following on social media because 1. He's completely adorable and squishy 2. To follow his medical journey. Due to his medical needs, baby Sulley requires 24/7 monitoring, and has been unable to be allowed back to daycare. In addition to the piles of medical bills that continually roll in from ER trips and hospital stays, the adjustment to Blake and Alaina's work schedules to accommodate one of them always being home with baby Sulley has begun to take its financial toll as well. These are hard times for everyone right now, but the Deshazo family truly needs some help, and I know there are many of us out there that follow their journey and would love to support them through this financial hardship. Please feel free to share this page and know that even the smallest donation will truly be appreciated beyond measure. For those of you who are new to baby Sulley's medical journey, here is an overview of his condition:Sulley was born at 34 weeks and spent two weeks in the NICU before coming home. He got bronchitis in December, then rhinovirus and enterovirus, then pneumonia... on underdeveloped preemie lungs. It was just too much on his little body. His immune system was so weak, he would catch anything. After a couple of hospital stays, he was referred to a pediatric pulmonologist. He ended up in the hospital again, where he was sent to Children’s Hospital. After his return home, he continued having problems and was referred to a pediatric cardiologist. He had testing on his lungs and heart. The cardiologist found a lot of pressure on his lungs, and after consulting with his pulmonologist, they determined that he has Pulmonary Hypertension. Sulley is now on full time oxygen.

help-in-the-fight-for-baby-theos-life.name: Theo
help-in-the-fight-for-baby-theos-life.title: Help with Baby Theo's Medical Expenses
help-in-the-fight-for-baby-theos-life.description:
Lauren and James need help to pay for medical bills and expenses that Baby Theo requires. Please donate what you can, and prayers are equally welcome.

 

Lauren and her husband James learned, during her pregnancy, that "Baby Theo" had a heart condition. They were presented with a choice to end the pregnancy or fight for Theo's life. They are a young Christian couple who researched the medical diagnosis and found that infants can survive with surgeries to lead happy lives. They chose to fight for Baby Theo's life. To get the needed medical care for Theo, they moved their household and young family from California to Texas. Theo's heart condition is hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), which requires specialized medical care and multiple surgeries over multiple years.

 

It was a blessing when Theo was born on January 5, 2022. Two days later, he had the Norwood heart surgery completed with a Sano and a second surgery the next day to adjust clips on the Sano. Theo has had numerous heart surgeries and is now at home with his family.

 

Until now, James and Lauren have been a dual-income family. They both worked for non-profit organizations to help others. Now they need OUR help. They have to pay mounting medical bills for scans, surgeries, specialists, recovery costs and household-related costs. In addition, one parent needs to care for Theo and his brother while the other needs to work to provide for the family. So, their costs have increased substantially, and their income has been reduced by half.

 

We are incredibly proud of the choice they made together to prioritize baby Theo's health and to fight for his life. As a result, they could use prayers and financial assistance for ongoing medical bills.

 

Thank you for your prayers and support.

baby-theodores-medical-support.name: Theodore
baby-theodores-medical-support.title: Baby Theodore’s Medical Support
baby-theodores-medical-support.description: Hi, my name is John and I’m raising funds to help cover the expenses of our baby Theodore in NICU (neonatal intensive care unit). Theodore was born on June 23, 2023, after a healthy pregnancy. He was a healthy 8 pounds and the birth seemed to have gone well, but a few minutes after birth it was clear that something wasn’t right. Little Theodore had trouble breathing and was put on supplemental oxygen. They hoped that supplemental oxygen for a while would take care of it, but after some ups and downs discovered bleeding from one lung as well, and after CO2 started to build up in his blood, they life flighted him to a level 4 NICU. They were able to stabilize him, but he was put on a ventilator and pretty strong meds to keep him from fighting the ventilator as well as to keep his vitals where they need to be. They don’t know what exactly happened or why and have run an enormous number of tests and scans which have ruled out physical abnormalities (congenial and other), infection, or injury. Doctors say they are optimistic, but this is likely to be weeks or months, not days, in the NICU. We live an hour’s drive away from the hospital, but distance-wise not far enough to get help from charities like Ronald McDonald house, and have an older sibling to care for as well, so have been commuting back and forth 1-2 times per day. We have medical insurance, but that will not cover all expenses either. Our finances are tight and we’re kindly asking for help to raise $20,000 to help with medical and costs related to commuting while Theodore is being treated in the NICU. We are very encouraged by you joining us in the journey and your financial help along the way.

vrbcp-medical-bill-assistance.name: Tobias
vrbcp-medical-bill-assistance.title: Medical bills for a great kid
vrbcp-medical-bill-assistance.description: Hi all and thank you for looking. Just recently my brother in laws kid had to go in for emergency brain surgery as they found a tumor on the back of his brain. He just came out and the surgery went well so they say but have to wait for additional tests of the tumor they removed. This was very unexpected and am positive that my sister in laws insurance won’t hardly cover anything and they are already stressing with the situation. They are a great family and our nephew Tobias is a great kid. Anything will help as I am starting this go fund me to get a jump start on the upcoming medical bills from this surgery. I know it may be more than the goal I have set. Or probably even more but it’s a start this way when they get that bill they can breathe a little bit. Thank you for listening. Funds will be used for the expected medical bills from the surgery and rehabilitation. Tobias is currently at Logan Health children’s ward in Kalispell Montana.

d6fcgz-stop-gun-violence.name: MeMe and Kay'Vion
d6fcgz-stop-gun-violence.title: Need Help Moving & Medical Expenses for my 3 & 6 yr. old
d6fcgz-stop-gun-violence.description:
I'm a tenant that lives in the apartments that was shot up (MiraMar) in Fort Worth last night off Las Vegas Trail and the West side of For Worth. My youngest (3 yr old) is still trying to pull through her injuries as she is putting up a big fight. She had her right kidney removed and the doctors are working diligently to get and keep her stable.

Her 6 year old brother was shot in the femur, where he is recovering well after his surgery. It will take a lot of physical therapy and a plate in his leg for at least one year for his recovery. The mental impact all of the children witnessed and suffered through the fear of losing their lives is something I could never imagine any child or human to ever have to experience. Thank you to the community family friends and loved ones for your continues prayers and support! It's time to acknowledge that gun violence should never be an option.

May God bless each and everyone of you and those who have been supporting and have supported, it's greatly appreciated.

help-4months-baby-girl-need-a-heart-surg.name: Anonymous
help-4months-baby-girl-need-a-heart-surg.disease: Ventricular Septal Defect, needs heart surgery
help-4months-baby-girl-need-a-heart-surg.title: Help my 4 months old Baby Girl, in need of a Heart Surgery
help-4months-baby-girl-need-a-heart-surg.description:
Help Me Save My Baby Girl’s Heart ❤️
